title: Minnesota Twins Add Relief Pitcher on Minor League Deal to Bolster Bullpen
description: Merryweather joins a revamped bullpen race, aiming to recapture his 2023 form amidst injury concerns.
fullText:
The Minnesota Twins signed right-handed reliever Julian Merryweather to a minor league contract with an invitation to spring training on Wednesday, adding another veteran arm to what has been an ongoing bullpen rebuild.

The 34-year-old will head to Fort Myers as a non-roster invitee and compete for a spot on the big league roster.

Merryweather was one of several moves the Twins made this week, as the club also signed former All-Star Liam Hendriks to a minor league deal and acquired left-hander Anthony Banda from the Los Angeles Dodgers.

All three moves point to an organization that knows it needs to rebuild its relief corps after last summer's trade deadline fire sale gutted the group.

Merryweather has pitched parts of six big league seasons between the Toronto Blue Jays and Chicago Cubs, putting together a career 4.72 ERA across 158.1 innings.

His best year came in 2023 with the Cubs when he posted a 3.38 ERA and racked up 98 strikeouts in 72 innings out of the bullpen, showing off the kind of stuff that makes him worth a look on a low-risk deal.

The Minnesota Twins have signed Julian Merryweather to a minor league contract. The pitcher has a 3.92 ERA along with 426 strikeouts throughout his minor league career. The contract includes an invitation to major league spring training. pic.twitter.com/9FxaJzjXJH

‚Äî Milb Central (@milb_central) February 13, 2026

Merryweather features a fastball that sits in the mid-90s and can touch 97 mph, along with a solid slider that gives him a real weapon against right-handed hitters.

The last two seasons have been a different story, though.

Injuries have slowed Merryweather down and his velocity has dipped, which led to a 6.15 ERA over just 33.2 innings combined in 2024 and 2025.

Last season he made 21 appearances for the Cubs before being released at the end of May, and he spent the rest of the year bouncing between minor league stints with the Mets and Brewers.

He posted a 5.87 ERA across 23 innings in Triple-A, so there are real questions about whether he can get back to where he was.

The Twins are coming off a 70-92 season that saw them finish fourth in the AL Central, and the bullpen was a big part of the problem.

Minnesota traded away key relievers like Jhoan Duran, Griffin Jax and Brock Stewart at the deadline last summer, leaving the group thin heading into 2026.

Right now the only real locks for the pen are Taylor Rogers, Justin Topa, Cole Sands and Kody Funderburk, which means there is a wide open path for guys like Merryweather to fight their way onto the roster this spring.

Merryweather still had some flashes in him last season. Another guy who could make the Opening Day roster if he has a healthy camp. https://t.co/lfsaaFci0P pic.twitter.com/6B1fwyupjl

‚Äî Cody Pirkl (@CodyPirkl) February 12, 2026

That lack of depth is exactly what has made Minnesota an attractive landing spot for veteran arms on minor league deals.

Merryweather joins a group of non-roster invitees that also includes Dan Altavilla, Matt Bowman and Grant Hartwig, all of whom will be looking to prove they belong.

If Merryweather can stay healthy and find his old fastball command, he has the kind of stuff that could play in the middle innings for a team that desperately needs pitching help heading into the new season.

Spring training will tell the story. It is a low-risk move for the Twins, and for Merryweather it is a chance to prove that his 2023 breakout was not a fluke.

title: Liam Hendriks Returns to Minnesota on Minor League Deal With Twins
description: A familiar face returns to the Twins.
fullText:
The Minnesota Twins are bringing back a familiar face, signing veteran reliever Liam Hendriks to a minor league contract with an invitation to major league spring training.

The deal reunites Hendriks with the franchise that gave him his start in professional baseball, as the 37-year-old looks to continue one of the most inspiring comeback stories in recent memory.

Hendriks was originally signed by Minnesota as a non-drafted free agent out of Perth, Australia, back in 2007, and he made his big league debut at Target Field on September 6, 2011.

He spent parts of three seasons with the Twins as a starting pitcher but struggled to find his footing, posting a 6.06 ERA in 30 games before the club designated him for assignment.

They could never make me hate Liam Hendriks. pic.twitter.com/UxjCbHIYll

‚Äî scott üß¶ (@FleecedByGetz) February 4, 2026

After bouncing around with the Blue Jays, Royals, and Athletics, Hendriks made the switch to the bullpen and everything changed.

From 2019 to 2022, he became one of the best closers in baseball, earning three All-Star selections while pitching for Oakland and the Chicago White Sox.

Over that four-year stretch, he recorded 114 saves with a 2.26 ERA and averaged 13.5 strikeouts per nine innings.

For his career, Hendriks owns a 33-36 record with 116 saves and a 3.88 ERA across 490 games.

The Twins are coming off a rough 2025 campaign where they went 70-92 and finished fourth in the AL Central.

Minnesota dealt away several key players at the trade deadline last summer, and the bullpen remains an area with plenty of question marks heading into 2026.

Liam Hendriks takes the mound for the first time in 681 days üíõ pic.twitter.com/iLWyt7dZgw

Manager Derek Shelton acknowledged the team does not have a clear closer and needs more right-handed experience out of the pen.

Adding a guy with Hendriks' resume on a no-risk minor league deal makes a lot of sense, especially when the pitching staff is still looking for answers across the board.

If Hendriks can get healthy and find anything close to his old form, he fills a massive need for a team trying to bounce back.

The simple answer is that the risk here is almost zero for the Twins.

It is a minor league deal, so the financial commitment is small, and Hendriks does not take up a spot on the 40-man roster unless the team decides to promote him.

That said, the concerns around his health are very real.

Hendriks has pitched just 18.2 innings over the last three seasons after battling non-Hodgkin lymphoma, Tommy John surgery, hip inflammation, and a nerve procedure in his elbow.

Liam Hendriks was Twins minor league pitcher of the year in 2011. That offseason I ranked him as their #5 prospect.

As you can see from my write-up, I never could have imagined him becoming a hard-throwing All-Star closer.

And neither could the Twins. They waived him at age 24. pic.twitter.com/8UePEjmBoX

‚Äî Aaron Gleeman (@AaronGleeman) February 12, 2026

He appeared in only 14 games for the Red Sox in 2025, going 0-2 with a 6.59 ERA in 13.2 innings before his season ended early.

The worry is that Hendriks' body simply may not hold up, and leaning on him in a late-inning role could leave the Twins scrambling if he goes down again.

Still, if there is anyone tough enough to make it work, it might be Hendriks.

His fight through cancer alone shows the kind of person he is, and the Twins are betting on that toughness to carry him through spring training and into a meaningful role in 2026. At worst, Minnesota loses nothing.

At best, they get a proven closer who can anchor the back end of a bullpen that badly needs one.

title: No. 1 Notre Dame-West Haven boys basketball shows depth in victory over No. 6 West Haven
description: With star player Abdou Tour in foul trouble, the Green Knights' Kadrian Reeves led the way with 20 points, and Landon Krygier reached a scoring milestone.
fullText:
WEST HAVEN - In the first meeting of the battle of West Haven on Dec. 23, Notre Dame boys basketball jumped out to a quick lead and won by 35 points. Round two was a bit different.

In a five-point game with less than five minutes to go, the No. 1 Green Knights went on a 14-4 run to defeat No. 6 West Haven 72-57 at Notre Dame High School on Thursday evening.

The Green Knights, who have not lost at home since 2018, won their seventh straight contest to improve to 16-3. Notre Dame also extended its in-state win streak to 29, with its last loss coming at Hillhouse in January 2025.

The Green Knights had to do things a little differently against their rivals Thursday when star Abdou Toure picked up his third foul with 2:39 left in the first quarter and his fourth foul with 2:17 left in the third.

With Toure out, Kadrian Reeves picked up the slack with a team-high 20 points.

"I have been saying it for a long time," Notre Dame coach Jason Shea said. "KK (Reeves) is one of the best three point guards in the state. We're not surprised by it. I think it's helped us the last five games without Abdou (Toure). We've been used to it, so I was very proud of him to step up in this game. He did a great job."

The frenetic pace of the Westies and the absence of Toure allowed West Haven to go into halftime even at 33. The Green Knights switched to a zone defense in the third quarter, and took a 55-49 lead to the fourth.

"Well, we came out in zone, which we haven't played much of all year, because of the foul trouble," Shea said of the third quarter. "I thought we did a decent job of just slowing the pace and fouling less. That allowed us to get out on the break more. I thought we did a nice job at halftime."

West Haven did not get closer, as Toure entered the game with 4:31 remaining and the Green Knights closed the contest with their decisive run.

"Like I said in December, we are going to be a better team the next time we see them," West Haven coach Tyrese Sullivan said after his team's 13-game winning streak was snapped, falling to 16-2. "When we see them again, we are going to be a better team, and when we see them again, we are going to be a better team. That's what I foresee.

"We'll be back. It's a regular season game that we wanted. I don't remember the last time anyone has won in here. The odds were stacked against us, and we were that close."

The Westies got as close as 62-57 on a bucket by Jordan Sirabionian, but the Green Knights scored the final 10 points of the game, including six by Landon Krygier to give him 1,002 points for his career.

Toure injured his quadricep in the first quarter against Branford on Jan. 21, sat the next four games, and returned to action in Notre Dame's last contest against Wilbur Cross.

The Notre Dame senior star, headed to Arkansas next season, finished with 11 points Thursday.

"We have enough depth," Shea said. "We showed that the last five or six games, but we have shown that in the past. We've had these situations before. This group has been together for years. We've played without (Toure) because of foul trouble, and we've played without him when he's been hurt. We don't like playing without him, but we can do it. There are plenty of guys out there who can step up and make plays."

Reeves scored the first six points of the game, as the Green Knights jumped out to an 8-1 lead. The pesky Westies got to within 20-18 on a pair of free throws by Loshon Roman, but baskets by Eli Ssenyange and Quincy Dormevil extended the Notre Dame lead to six points.

"It was a rival game," Reeves said. "We knew they were going to play hard. We came and responded to them playing hard first."

A basket by Reeves and a 3-pointer by Toure started the third quarter, before a 3-pointer by Roman got West Haven as close as 42-39. A dunk by Aaron Johnson got West Haven to within 47-44 with 2:55 left in the third, but the Westies never got within three points again.

"We have a lot of depth on our team," Reeves said. "We have eight seniors and some juniors. We just had to step up this game. Everybody had to step up."

Sirabionian had a game-high 24 points for West Haven, while Johnson finished with nine points.

Krygier finished with 11 points for the Green Knights, and Ssenyange added nine.

Kadrian Reeves, Notre Dame: The junior finished with 20 points, including 13 in the third quarter when the Green Knights extended their lead.

"We've got 10 or 11 guys who can really make a difference in a game. We trust those guys, and we just go with the hot hands on any given night. I thought they did try to push tempo, but we're comfortable with that pace too. Tonight, it was just better for us to get settled in." - Notre Dame coach Jason Shea.

WEST HAVEN¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬†18 15 16¬† ¬†8-57
ND-WEST HAVEN¬† ¬† 24¬† ¬†9 22 17-72

West Haven: Brandon Bellamy 0 1 0-0 3, K'naan Morris 1 2 0-0 8, Jordan Sirabionian 7 0 10-13 24, Loshon Roman 1 1 3-6 8, Aaron Johnson 3 1 0-0 9, Trew Kitson 1 0 1-2 3, Ricardo Harris 1 0 0-0 2. Totals: 14 5 14-21 57.
Notre Dame: Abdou Toure 2 1 4-4 11, Landon Krygier 2 1 4-4 11, Quincy Dormevil 3 0 0-0 6, Jonathan Jones 3 0 2-2 8, Kadrian Reeves 6 2 2-3 20, George Ganim 1 0 0-0 2, Eli Ssenyange 2 1 2-4 9, Tyrell Bryant 0 0 2-2 2, Jovan Lakaj 1 0 1-2 3. Totals: 20 5 17-21 72.¬†
Team records: West Haven 16-2, ND-West Haven 16-3.

This article originally published at No. 1 Notre Dame-West Haven boys basketball shows depth in victory over No. 6 West Haven.

title: Kinziger leads ISU to much-needed win over Valparaiso, 86-64
description: NORMAL, Ill. (WMBD/WYZZ) ‚Äî Johnny Kinziger scored 21 points to lead Illinois State to an 86-64 win over Valparaiso at CEFCU Arena on Thursday night. The Redbirds scored 52 points in the second half and returned to the win column after a Monday loss to Evansville, the team at the bottom of the Missouri Valley [‚Ä¶]
fullText:
NORMAL, Ill. (WMBD/WYZZ) ‚Äî Johnny Kinziger scored 21 points to lead Illinois State to an 86-64 win over Valparaiso at CEFCU Arena on Thursday night.

The Redbirds scored 52 points in the second half and returned to the win column after a Monday loss to Evansville, the team at the bottom of the Missouri Valley Conference standings. Freshman Ty‚ÄôReek Coleman came off the bench to score 14 points and grab five rebounds for the Redbirds (17-9, 9-6).

The Redbirds had a 14-0 run in the second half and outscored the Beacons 32-12 in the game‚Äôs final 12 minutes. Kinziger made 7-of-15 shots from the floor in earning his season-high total of 21 points.

‚ÄúIt feels good to see a couple shots go in. But my main role is to be a captain, a leader of this team,‚Äù Kinziger said. ‚ÄúNo matter if the ball is going in or not, I‚Äôm just trying to do that to the best of my ability.‚Äù

ISU center Chase Walker scored 11 points and played only six minutes of action. Redbird coach Ryan Pedon said Walker suffered a hamstring injury in the first half.

Even without Walker‚Äôs presence, ISU outscored Valpo, 42-24, in the paint.

‚ÄúI thought every guy that contributed tonight really played a very important role, and I think this was a very important victory for us tonight,‚Äù Pedon said.

The Redbirds play at UIC on Sunday.

title: LeBron James becomes the oldest NBA player in history to get a triple-double
description: LeBron James made sure to get a triple-double during the Lakers' matchup against the Mavericks to become the oldest player to get one.
fullText:
LeBron James becomes the oldest NBA player in history to get a triple-double originally appeared on The Sporting News. Add The Sporting News as a Preferred Source by clicking here.

LeBron James has always been one of the most impressive players in NBA history. In his younger years, he was always setting records for being the youngest player to do something.

Now that he is 23 years into his NBA career, he is setting records for being the oldest player to do something. On Thursday, James had a triple-double for the Los Angeles Lakers against the Dallas Mavericks, marking another record for the 41-year-old.

Now that he is 41 years old, LeBron continues to be one of the most impressive athletes out there. Most NBA players have retired by this point, but he is still going strong for the Lakers.

He is not only playing, but he is playing well on a good team. That is just a testament to how well James has taken care of his body over the years, and his natural talent being higher than almost everyone else.

MORE:¬†Lakers' LeBron James ends NBA record streak that is unlikely to be matched any time soon

Against the Mavericks, James had a triple-double with his 28 points, 10 rebounds, and 12 assists. He almost did not get his 10th rebound because Austin Reaves was fighting him for boards.

Head coach JJ Redick was pleased to see James get another achievement, as he is always proud to be his head coach at the tail-end of his career.

"I don't take for granted how good he is. I recognize that on a daily basis. The more remarkable thing is how much he cares in his 23rd year with all his accomplishments. He's got a 23-year prime basically," Redick said after the win against Dallas.

Now, James is the oldest player to get a triple-double at 41. That is possibly one of the toughest records to ever beat because most players struggle to perform in their mid-30s.

However, LeBron continues to stand out even if he is in his record-setting 23rd season. James seems ready to play more seasons, which is proof of his all-time greatness.

title: K League in 2025-2026 AFC Champions League Match Day 7 Recap
description: AFC Champions League Match Day 7 proved to be one of disappointment for K League's continental contingent. No wins, two draws and two losses across the two competitions leave work to be done for FC Se...
fullText:
AFC Champions League Match Day 7 proved to be one of disappointment for K League's continental contingent. No wins, two draws and two losses across the two competitions leave work to be done for FC Seoul, Gangwon FC and Ulsan HD to reach the ACLE knockouts, while Pohang Steelers will have to earn a win in Japan to reach the ACL Two quarterfinals.

It proved to be a disappointing start to 2026 forFC Seoul, losing 2-0 to Vissel Kobe in Japan on Tuesday. There were debuts for six players: Gu Sung-yun in goal, Juan Antonio Ros at centre back,¬†Hrvoje Babec and Song Jeong-beom in central midfield, Song Min-kyu at left wing, and Leonardo Ruiz in attack, but the capital club suffered the same fortunes from the tail-end of 2025.

Kobe controlled possession, limiting Seoul to just two shots on target. A scoreline of 0-0 at half time will have given Kim Gi-dong and his men some satisfaction, but goals from Muto¬†Yoshinori and Sakai¬†Gotoku in the space of four minutes, striking on 69 and 73 minutes respectively, dealt two hammer blows that Seoul couldn't recover from.

K League's capital club have their knockout qualification destiny in their own hands, sitting sixth but with just a one-point lead. They face Sanfrecce Hiroshima next - at Mokdong and not Sangam - in their final league phase match. Sanfrecce will head to Korea on the back of back-to-back wins and a run of four unbeaten in ACL.

Gangwon FC's 0-0 draw with Chinese Super League champions Shanghai Port on Wednesday, on paper, represents a good result, but a single point earned, and now no wins in four, leaves the Bears clinging on to the last qualification place.

Goh Young-jun made his Bears bow as a starter, while Israeli striker¬†Abdalla Halaihal came off the bench as a late sub, replacing Goh, but it was a game where Gangwon just couldn't find a breakthrough.

Gangwon had 62% possession, 11 shots but just two found the target, while Shanghai Port managed just two shots and neither hit the target. Jeong Kyung-ho's men sit eighth on eight points and will need to go to Melbourne and beat City to guarantee a place in the knockouts.

Ulsan HD began the Kim Hyun-seok era with a 2-1 loss at home to Melbourne City. The result will have been a tough one to take, owing to a late, late Melbourne winner with Marcus Younis finding the back of the net in the 93rd minute.

Darijan Bojanic equalised for the Horangi on 80 minutes, cancelling out Max Caputo's 37th-minute opener, but despite having thetiger's share of possession with 60% and 10 shots, it was a second ACLE loss in succession for Ulsan.

Ulsan sit one place outside the knockout qualification group, but level on points with Gangwon and Johor Darul Ta'zim. They face Shanghai Port next away from home, needing to win to advance.

Pohang Steelers came from behind to earn an ACL Two Round of 16 draw at home to Gamba Osaka. Yamashita Ryoya gave the J.League outfit the lead just after the restart, but Jorge Teixeira was able to offer a reply on 71 minutes. Nishiya Kento was the only Steelers debutant, starting in central midfield in a 4-1-4-1.

Pohang had to cede possession for the most part, but were able to out-edge Gamba in terms of shots and shots on target (14-12, 4-3). The result leaves the tie delicately poised ahead of next week's second leg in Osaka.

title: Surprise Chelsea player in the shadows could get shock start vs Hull tonight
description: A player who many will know little about, Teddy Sharman-Lowe, could be in line for a shock start for Chelsea this evening.I think it will be a stretch to see him start to be honest, but manager Liam R...
fullText:
A player who many will know little about, Teddy Sharman-Lowe, could be in line for a shock start for Chelsea this evening.

I think it will be a stretch to see him start to be honest, but manager Liam Rosenior has been dropping some hints suggesting that we could see the backup goalkeeper get some game time.

Chelsea‚Äôs usual number two stopper, Filip Jorgensen, is apparently injured right now. So that means number one keeper, Robert Sanchez, is currently playing every game. I know goalkeepers don‚Äôt need to rest as much as outfield players do because they run much more. But there is the element of a mental rest being needed too.

And maybe Chelsea‚Äôs FA Cup tie against Hull City tonight might be where Rosenior decides he can rest Sanchez, even if that would be a huge and risky call and certainly a shock one.

Teddy Sharman-Lowe playing for Doncaster. (Photo by Justin Setterfield/Getty Images)

Sharman-Lowe, who was recalled early from a season long loan move with Bolton Wanderers, is ready to be called on.

In words cited on X, Rosenior said:

‚ÄúFilip [Jorgensen] is not fully fit at the moment. He‚Äôs working really, really hard on his rehab. Teddy [Sharman-Lowe] has had a really important loan at this stage of his career. He‚Äôs been showing really good things in training as well, so I‚Äôve got no worries if we have to call upon him.‚Äù

Jamie Carragher does not rate Chelsea‚Äôs summer signing of Liam Delap and believes the striker should have gone to a lesser club before he moved to a big club like Chelsea, making the switch from Ipswich Town.

Meanwhile, Chelsea are considering offering a contract to Bournemouth centre back Marcos Senesi if/when he becomes a free agent at the end of this season.

title: VIDEO: No. 15 Wall Hawks look to stay perfect in district, No. 1 Lady Hawks gear up for playoffs
description: SAN ANGELO, Texas (Concho Valley Homepage) ‚Äî Playoff season is on the horizon for the Wall Hawks and Lady Hawks. The Wall Hawks and Lady Hawks have soared over district opponents all season long. Both teams are district champions, and the Hawks look to match the Lady Hawks‚Äô perfect 12-0 record. With two regular season [‚Ä¶]
fullText:
SAN ANGELO, Texas (Concho Valley Homepage) ‚Äî Playoff season is on the horizon for the Wall Hawks and Lady Hawks.

The Wall Hawks and Lady Hawks have soared over district opponents all season long. Both teams are district champions, and the Hawks look to match the Lady Hawks‚Äô perfect 12-0 record.

With two regular season games remaining, the No. 15 Hawks have aspirations of completing an undefeated district record. Head coach Parker Roberts‚Äô squad stands tall at 10-0, set to face current second-place holder Jim Ned Friday night. Wall narrowly held off Jim Ned 50-44 on Jan 20, as the Hawks go for the season sweep. Although Wall has already secured its District 6-3A Region I title, the goal hasn‚Äôt changed. The coaches‚Äô and players‚Äô mindset simply revolves around focusing on one game at a time.

‚ÄúThe biggest thing for [Wall] is just trying to focus on one game at a time,‚Äù Roberts said. ‚ÄúBeing this close and us already knowing that we‚Äôre the one seed, we try not to look to far ahead to the playoffs already. [We must] take care of the two games that we have left and keep that mindset one game at a time, because when you get to the playoffs it‚Äôs one game at a time.‚Äù

On the Lady Hawks‚Äô side, head coach Silas Crisler‚Äôs team begins gearing up for its upcoming postseason run. No. 1 Wall faces Brady in the bi-district round at Winters High School on Monday, Feb 16. In Crisler‚Äôs vision, toughness is what makes the Lady Hawks the team to beat.

‚ÄúI have told our girls and they believe it that we are the toughest team in Texas,‚Äù Crisler said. ‚ÄúWe say that with pride and we live it out every day. We‚Äôre going to continue that every single playoff game.‚Äù

In the players‚Äô vision, team chemistry and depth define the group‚Äôs identity.

‚ÄúWe not only have a starting five, we have a great five coming off the bench,‚Äù senior point guard Kathrine Lewis said. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre very versatile. If somebody tries to shut someone down, we have another girl coming in to take her spot. No one‚Äôs better than each other. We all have our own strengths that all go into the team and help us pull out wins.‚Äù

title: Why Is Trai Hume Currently Our Fashionable Scapegoat?
description: ‚ÄúThe idea that the Northern Ireland international has suddenly become a weak link just doesn‚Äôt stack up‚Äù.
fullText:
It‚Äôs a familiar movie, with the same script, a different director and different subject matter, yet the same core theme ‚Äî a Sunderland player becoming a lightning rod for the team‚Äôs failure to perform on any given day.

For years, the starring role was played by Luke O‚ÄôNien, ludicriously branded a ‚Äúliability‚Äù (a word I‚Äôd gladly see cast out of all Sunderland-related discourse ‚Äî there are no liabilities in this team) and viewed in some circles as a weak link and someone who couldn‚Äôt trap a football, let alone play a key role in our eventual rise to the Premier League.

It was untrue then; it‚Äôs still untrue now, and although we might‚Äôve hoped that singling out certain players for often disproportionate criticism is a habit we‚Äôd try to break, it‚Äôs nonetheless disheartening that as Sunderland‚Äôs form has hit choppier waters, a wholehearted, committed and high-quality footballer in Trai Hume has found himself under the microscope.

Let‚Äôs nail something down: pound for pound, Hume is one of the best, most effective and successful signings made by Sunderland during Kristjaan Speakman‚Äôs time at the club.

When he arrived from Linfield in 2022, he had the feel of a low-risk, ‚Äúone for the future‚Äù-type signing but during four years in red and white, his ferocious will to win and refusal to take a backwards step have been a key component of Sunderland‚Äôs rise from League One to the Premier League.

He‚Äôs also far more technically accomplished than we often highlight and his low-key attitude is a perfect fit for the times: no nonsense and no razzle-dazzle ‚Äî just a rugged approach to the game that R√©gis Le Bris and his teammates clearly appreciate.

Why, therefore, has Hume suddenly become such a polarising figure among pockets of the fanbase?

Yes, recent results have been average and our performance levels aren‚Äôt currently hitting the heights that they did earlier in the campaign, but as Le Bris is often at pains to point out, collectivism is the name of the game at the Stadium of Light and it was good to hear him offer some staunch backing for Hume earlier this week.

OK, the absence of Bertrand Traor√© and the spectre of Lutsharel Geertruida (a superb and extremely versatile player in his own right) may be factors here, but the idea that the Northern Ireland international has suddenly become a weak link just doesn‚Äôt stack up.

Perhaps Le Bris is asking Hume ‚Äî a hard-tackling right back by trade ‚Äî to push his versatility a shade too far at times, but that‚Äôs not on Hume himself and after a challenging afternoon against West Ham, has he not handled himself well as captain during the subsequent clashes with Burnley, Arsenal and Liverpool on Wednesday night?

Let‚Äôs be frank: Granit Xhaka‚Äôs absence has forced the head coach to adapt and the results have been mixed, but hanging a player out to dry because he‚Äôs perhaps not living up to your expectations in a role he‚Äôs still learning is hardly sound reasoning.

Collectively, Sunderland weren‚Äôt anywhere near their best against Liverpool.

On reflection, it seemed as though we showed the visitors too much respect, and there was a timidity to our play that I found slightly puzzling at times, with safe passes being chosen too often for my liking and Alisson not really being troubled for the majority of the game.

This isn‚Äôt entirely attributable to Hume, however, and if we‚Äôre going to analyse where things aren‚Äôt quite clicking for Sunderland, it‚Äôs grossly unfair to turn on a player who‚Äôs demonstrated throughout the season that he does have Premier League quality and for whom the step up from the Championship has not proven impossible to make.

He‚Äôs doing what‚Äôs being asked of him; he‚Äôs doing it to the best of his ability and if Le Bris opts to bring Geertruida into the fold for Sunday‚Äôs FA Cup tie at Oxford or next Sunday‚Äôs league meeting with Fulham, I‚Äôm sure Hume, as a double promotion winner and one of our longest-serving players, will respond as professionally as possible.

On a final note, it should be highlighted that legitimate and constructive criticism of players‚Äô performances is fine.

That‚Äôs part of the deal, but I really do wish we‚Äôd take a moment before tossing words such as ‚Äòliability‚Äù around so flippantly and laying into players with unnecessary venom. It adds nothing the discussion and potentially does more harm than good ‚Äî not least given the scrutiny these lads are already under as they compete in such a tough and demanding league.

title: Can Sunderland Find Inspiration In The FA Cup?
description: With a pause in league action, can the Lads use the trip to Oxford as a chance to rebuild following consecutive losses?
fullText:
Suffering back-to-back league defeats and losing our impervious home record were tough blows to take but losing to one of the best teams in the world ‚Äî and the reigning league champions at that ‚Äî is nothing to be ashamed of.

Oxford provides a good opportunity to get back on track, but I know they won‚Äôt make it easy for us. They‚Äôre struggling in the league and without a win in four games, so they might see the FA Cup as a good opportunity to lift the fans and instil some hope for the rest of the season.

With this in mind, I think R√©gis Le Bris will field as strong a team as possible this weekend.

In the last round against Everton, I thought we would rotate and focus more on the league, but I was proved wrong and a strong eleven helped us progress into the next round. Of course, Everton are a much better side than Oxford but Le Bris seems interested in the FA Cup and its possibilities, so I wouldn‚Äôt be too surprised if we did see a good team take to the field this weekend.

However, the Lads have had a tough and demanding week. Games against Arsenal and Liverpool would‚Äôve taken a lot out of them and that may force Le Bris‚Äô hand in terms of rotating the squad.

I remember in the run-up to the Everton game, he said that he would speak to each player and see if they were up to it ‚Äî and I presume he will have followed the same procedure this week. I wonder whether Melker Ellborg will get his first start in goal on Sunday, and maybe Jocelin Ta Bi will be in the squad for the first time since his arrival.

I‚Äôd like to see the best side available to us play this weekend, but whether that‚Äôll happen is a different story. By 1:00pm on Sunday, our questions will be answered and an idea of our chances in this competition may be clearer.

Losing twice on the bounce is an unusual feeling for Sunderland fans but it‚Äôs worth remembering that thanks to the quirks of the fixture computer, we‚Äôve played last season‚Äôs champions and this season‚Äôs champions-elect ‚Äî with a game against Manchester City thrown into the tough run of matches.

That being considered, it‚Äôs still been a very positive and uplifting season and for the first time a long while, the FA Cup offers us definite hope and possibilities.

We haven‚Äôt got the punishing, continuous run of midweek games that teams in the EFL or in Europe are dealing with.

We also aren‚Äôt in a relegation fight, so the FA Cup can be a positive distraction from our league matches. From all the interviews and messages coming out of the club, it sounds as though this is the case; in fact, Noah Sadiki actually said that the cup is ‚Äújust as important as the league games‚Äù. Nice to hear.

Consecutive defeats might‚Äôve dented any European hopes that some of the more positive-minded fans might be hoping for (myself included), so the cup tie could be coming at exactly the right time to reignite the squad and fans, and to give us something to battle for on a different front.

No matter how proud we should be of a potential mid-table position come the end of the season, it nevertheless gives the players little incentive to pull out all the stops and do battle in every game ‚Äî an FA Cup run can give us that.

So although I expect a few changes this weekend (some perhaps forced), I‚Äôm certain we‚Äôll put out a strong team and take Oxford very seriously.¬†Being in the hat for round five could start to awaken some imaginations!

I‚Äôm looking forward to the game and I do hope we progress, as after a tough few Premier League games (with a good result against Burnley in the middle) we certainly need something to pick the Lads and the fans back up.

I‚Äôm the sort of fan who appreciates that we‚Äôre likely to lose to Arsenal and Liverpool during our first season back at the top level and that taking points from these teams again this season always was a tough ask after doing well previously.

That‚Äôs especially true when such games are so close together and we‚Äôve recently been without our skipper.

Despite only taking two points from twelve available, these are established elite teams and that isn‚Äôt a bad haul for a team such as ourselves. I also get that defeat is a painful pill to swallow, amplified by Sunderland not playing as well as we know we can ‚Äî although the Arsenal performance wasn‚Äôt bad at all, other than the score.

Oxford is a place many of us went to when we were back in the doldrums of League One, and I have fond memories of the away end limbs and Elliot Embleton scoring for us as we progressed the part of our journey.

The side we take to their weird, three-sided stadium will be very different from the eleven that faced Arsenal and Liverpool, but it‚Äôs a great chance for some of the fringe players to get some minutes and for more relationships to be matured and solidified.

It‚Äôs also a chance for some players to rest a little and to enjoy the thrill of the FA Cup from the bench if needed, whilst maybe recovering and getting ready for the next Premier League challenge to come.

In short, this is a fresh breath of air where we can rotate, still play some good football and hopefully progress to the next round without too much fuss and bother ‚Äî ideally with zero injuries to our Premier League starters.

On the day, I‚Äôd like to see more of Lutsharel Geertruida, Wilson Isidor, Romaine Mundle, Eliezer Mayenda, Dennis Cirkin, Chris Rigg and maybe our new goalkeeper Melker Ellborg. Drop a smattering of the first eleven around that and we should have enough to prevail.

We‚Äôre pretty safe in the league, so let‚Äôs give this a go and put a smile back on all our faces before the league returns.

title: Announcement: K League United signs partnership MOU with Record Pizza & TNT FC
description: K League United is delighted to announce that it has signed a memorandum of understanding for a partnership with Record Pizza and TNT FC for the 2026 season.The agreement establishes a collaborative f...
fullText:
K League United is delighted to announce that it has signed a memorandum of understanding for a partnership with Record Pizza and TNT FC for the 2026 season.

The agreement establishes a collaborative framework across media production, brand exposure, and club promotion, creating a new model linking Korean division football with a global football content platform.

The MOU is multifaceted. Record Pizza will sponsor K League United Podcasts and website content, while TNT FC will grant exclusive access for K League United to tell the story of one of the most unique clubs in Korea‚Äôs football division system.

Through the partnership, K League United will feature the Record Pizza brand across our media platforms and host football events and cultural content at Record Pizza for fans of various nationalities residing in Korea.

Yangcheon TNT FC will benefit from K League United‚Äôs global media network, allowing the club‚Äôs story and player development journeys to reach overseas audiences. As part of the collaboration, K League United will spotlight TNT FC through a dedicated ‚ÄúTNT FC Corner‚Äù on the podcast, monthly feature articles, and Player in Focus content, with the aim of expanding the club‚Äôs international fanbase and highlighting the grassroots spirit of lower-division football.

Paul Neat, Co-Editor-in-Chief of K League United, said, ‚ÄúWe felt that the philosophy and values pursued by K League United are very similar to the direction TNT FC is heading in,‚Äù adding, ‚ÄúWe look forward to creating synergy in various ways through collaboration with Record Pizza and TNT FC.‚Äù

Kim Seok-young, CEO of Record Pizza, stated, ‚ÄúThis agreement goes beyond simple brand exposure and marks a meaningful starting point for creating storytelling-based sports content together. Through a new media collaboration model connecting fans, brands, and clubs, we aim to grow alongside sports culture.‚Äù

Kim Tae-ryung, CEO of Yangcheon TNT FC, added, ‚ÄúThis is a great opportunity to deliver news of Korean division football not only to foreigners living in Korea but also to global football fans. We are grateful to K League United for proposing this collaboration, and we look forward to global media, a sports pub, and a football club working together to create fresh projects.‚Äù

This agreement is significant in that it goes beyond a simple sponsorship and represents a cooperative model in which media, brand, and club are organically connected. Record Pizza will expand the sports fan experience, TNT FC will secure global exposure, and K League United will strengthen content diversity and on-the-ground storytelling in a mutually complementary structure.

title: How to watch Texas athletes Amber Glenn, Hannah Bilka and more compete in Winter Olympics
description: As the Winter Olympics continue, there are four Texas athletes competing for gold. What is their schedule and how to watch them?
fullText:
The Winter Olympics in Milan Cortina are underway and out of the thousands of Olympians, four come the state of Texas.

Representing the Lone Star State are Amber Glenn from¬†Plano and Emily Chan from Pasadena, men's bobsledder¬†Boone Niederhofer from San Antonio and women's hockey forward¬†Hannah¬†Bilka from Coppell.

As of Friday, some of these athletes have yet to compete, so there's still plenty of chances to cheer on the Texans in their pursuit of gold. The 2026 Olympic Games don't end until Feb. 22.

MORE: After 'scary amount' of threats, Texas Olympics figure skater steps back from social media

MORE: ¬†Which state dominates the Olympics ‚Äî and how does Texas compare?

Here is a schedule for the Texas Olympians:

Glenn already won gold as a member of Team USA's figure skating team event; it's the second straight gold for the U.S. in the event.¬†After finishing¬†Glenn third during her skate in the team event, she still has to the chance for an individual medal.

She will take the ice at 11:45 a.m. Tuesday at Milano Ice Skating Arena for her short program and at noon Thursday for her free skate.

Chan¬†has a chance to add an Olympic medal to her the silvers she's earned in other competitions while competing for Texas USA.

She and skating partner Spencer¬†Howe compete at 12:45 p.m. Sunday at Milano Ice Skating Arena in¬†the¬†short program and 1 p.m. Monday¬†is their free skate.

The differences between a short program and a free skate are¬†timing and what is being showcased on the ice, according to the NBC Olympics website. A short program is a technical routine no more than 2 minutes, 40 seconds while a free skate lasts four minutes that can showcase the athlete's artistry.

Niederhofer, a former Texas A&M football walk-on¬†will be a member of the four-man team. Two-man runs will continue Feb. 16-17 for the men with the medal run happening at 11:35 p.m. The four-man run finals begin Sunday morning, Feb. 22.

Team USA has been dominating the competition with Bilka leading the way. The Coppell native scored two goals in the 5-0 rout¬†of rival Canada¬†; she has three goals¬†in Olympic competition.

Since going undefeated in the preliminary round, the U.S. is preparing for a Friday¬†game against Italy. If the U.S. wins, the semifinal game will be Monday with the date of the gold medal game to be determined.

title: How Do You Fill A Xhaka-Shaped Hole In Sunderland‚Äôs Team?
description: Spoiler alert: you can‚Äôt. Not properly, anyway.
fullText:
Losing away at Arsenal (the soon-to-be Premier League champions) and then at home against Liverpool (the reigning trophy-holders) is not the disaster that some social media dwellers would have you believing if you took their words with anything more than a shovelful of salt.

Yes, it‚Äôs perfectly understandable that Sunderland would drop points against such weighty opponents, yet rather predictably, the inquest started during and after Wednesday‚Äôs defeat at the hands of Arne Slot‚Äôs side.

I won‚Äôt even repeat some of the things that I saw myself, but I‚Äôm sure you, reading this, will have also seen criticism of certain players layered in hyperbole and drama.

It‚Äôs seemingly in the eyes of some people no longer acceptable to have the odd off day, or for players to go through periods of struggle. Instead, they‚Äôre just labelled as shite, treated like morons, and talked about like they‚Äôre carrying a serious contagious disease, as though we really ought not to be associated with them.

Most irritatingly for me, anyway, this stuff is levelled at lads who played for us in the Championship, and we owe a great amount of gratitude to them for even being in a position where we can lose to a team like Liverpool in a league game. They‚Äôre also young, which adds extra layers of complexity, as we know for a fact that young players read and see the words written about them online.

Am I saying you mustn‚Äôt criticise players if they haven‚Äôt played well? Absolutely not. They‚Äôre in a position where they are being judged constantly, so it‚Äôs only natural that we would.

But, whatever happened to just being sensible and rational? Some of them are only playing such a significant role, or in unfamiliar positions, because more senior and capable players aren‚Äôt available right now.

To a lesser degree, I think it‚Äôs fair to say that it‚Äôs been tough replacing the experience and creativity of Bertrand Traor√© on our right-hand side, and once he does return it will be a welcome one, but I think we have enough about us in the squad to cope with not having him for what will eventually be just over two months, factoring in the time he was away at AFCON and then through injury since returning.

The far more difficult and, dare I say, impossible task is to replace Granit Xhaka. We have many great players, and I really think the future is bright when I watch Sunderland‚Äôs midfielders strut their stuff, but there really isn‚Äôt another player out there that‚Äôs attainable that could do what Granit Xhaka does for this team.

His leadership qualities alone are simply irreplaceable. He directs traffic, he demands that everyone meet the standards that he does, and he strikes fear into our opponents. Players and coaches know that when they‚Äôre facing a midfield that can call upon the skillset of Granit Xhaka, they‚Äôre in for an infinitely tougher afternoon than they would be against most other teams in the division. Then there‚Äôs what he brings on the pitch from a playing standpoint ‚Äî he‚Äôs our greatest creative source, is a world-class passer of the ball, and dictates the tempo of games. These are skills that he‚Äôs honed over many years; skills you simply wouldn‚Äôt expect from your average 21-year-old just making their first big strides onto the world‚Äôs stage.

All of that said, it amazes me that people are scrabbling around looking to find difficult answers to what are simple questions. The noticeable drop-off in Sunderland‚Äôs performances recently, Burnley aside, can mostly be put down to the fact that we‚Äôre missing our best player.

The reason the manager continues to play Trai Hume out of position is that without Granit, we lack leadership, defensive cover, and bite in midfield, which is a quality that Trai provides.

Is it really that difficult to understand, or am I oversimplifying things? That doesn‚Äôt exempt R√©gis from criticism when he gets some of his decisions wrong, but given the fact that he got us promoted and then we‚Äôve had such an unbelievable season, he‚Äôs built up a significant amount of credit and respect, and that should make people think more than twice about questioning his decision-making.

It‚Äôs probably difficult to do this when the games are coming thick and fast, but I really wish that people who get aggravated regardless of who we lose to ‚Äî whether that be one of the best teams walking the planet, or a team fighting for their survival ‚Äî would just take a breath, have a think, and put their phones down before they tweet something silly. It doesn‚Äôt help anyone, really.

We‚Äôve already far exceeded my expectations for the season, and with survival virtually guaranteed, anything else we do from this point is a bonus. We‚Äôll probably lose a good few more games this season, but we‚Äôll also win games, and hopefully we can get that winning feeling back again, starting on Sunday at Oxford.

In R√©gis I trust‚Ä¶ and hopefully you do, too.

title: A.J. Brown trade rumors: Steelers, Patriots among 5 best fits, likely landing spots for Eagles WR
description: The Eagles may still be shopping their star wide receiver despite an offensive coordinator change. Here's looking at the best potential suitors to acquire his services for 2026 and beyond.
fullText:
A.J. Brown trade rumors: Steelers, Patriots among 5 best fits, likely landing spots for Eagles WR originally appeared on The Sporting News. Add The Sporting News as a Preferred Source by clicking here.

The Philadelphia Eagles need to decide soon on whether they want to keep wide receiver A.J. Brown as part of their offensive plans for 2026. The mercurial playmaker is among the top candidates to get traded in a blockbuster deal in the NFL offseason.

Although the team hired a new offensive coordinator, Sean Mannion, to help them restore a top down field passing game with Jalen Hurts, they can still consider moving Brown should the right offer come along.

Here's looking at the teams to watch most for landing Brown:

MORE:¬†Ranking the top 100 free agents in 2026 NFL offseason

Brown reuniting with former Eagles offensive coordinator Kellen Moore makes a lot of sense. The Saints need to hack away with their latest salary cap issues, but they should be interested in making room for Brown as the ideal big-play No. 1 for strong-armed second-year QB Tyler Shough. Brown and Chris Olave would be a tough 1-2 punch in the passing game, resetting New Orleans' offensive ceiling.

The Saints could use the No. 8 overall pick to trade for Brown if needed and if not, they can offer a package that includes No. 42 overall in the second round. This would be a big, immediate impact move for the Saints to improve with no transition needed for Brown.

The Raiders need to work on their offensive line most for presumed No. 1 overall pick, rookie starting QB Fernando Mendoza. They already have a couple of top-flight first-round playmakers in running back Asthon Jeanty and tight end Brock Bowers. The missing piece is a go-to wide receiver as they have parted ways with Davante Adams and Jakobi Meyers in the middle of the past two seasons. Giving Mendoza a weapon of Brown's caliber to stretch the field would better open up the rushing attack for Jeanty and the intermediate passing routes for Bowers.

The Raiders have a ton of money under the cap to lock up Brown with a contract extension and should be able to be make it work to acquire him in a package that involves their second-round pick (No. 36 overall).

The 49ers are blowing up their receiving corps with Brandon Aiyuk set to be dealt and Jauan Jennings primed to depart in free agency. They also don't know when tight end George Kittle can get to full speed from his late Achilles' injury. Brock Purdy is in a tough spot with his weapons beyond Christian McCaffrey and third-year first-rounder Ricky Perasall. If Philadelphia could work a trade with a fellow NFC playoff team, then this would make sense.

Brown would take over as the Niners' top wideout and mesh well with Purdy's deep passing accuracy. San Francisco can offer the No. 27 overall pick in the first round for Brown and it can also make it work salary-wise, already being more than $40 million under the cap.

MORE:¬†Sporting News' latest mock draft with order finalized

The Patriots improved by 10 games and got to Super Bowl 60 in part because they were rather aggressive in spending in free agency at the right spots, including signing former Eagles' defensive tackle Milton Williams. Now they should be looking at Philadelphia again to give Drake Maye, another accurate downfield passer, a true big-play No. 1 to help upgrade from the mix of Stefon Diggs, Kayshon Boutte and Mack Hollins.

New England should be OK parting ways with the No. 31 overall pick in the first round as part of the Eagles' compensation. The Patriots can also provide a solid former Titans reunion between Brown and coach Mike Vrabel.

The Steelers would be the dark horse of the group, but there's some appeal to having Brown reunite with former Ole Miss teammate DK Metcalf and give Aaron Rodgers a pair of dangerous downfield targets. Brown can take over as a more reliable No. 1 and set up Metcalf to operate better as a No. 2 with more favorable coverage outside and inside.

Pittsburgh can be the most aggressive and offer the No. 21 overall pick in a deal to land Brown. The team can also splurge a little, being around $45 million under the salary cap.

title: What Jazz coach Will Hardy said about the team getting fined by the NBA for sitting its stars
description: On Thursday, the NBA announced just 30 minutes before the Utah Jazz‚Äôs home game against the Portland Trail Blazers that it was fining the Jazz $500,000 for ‚Äúconduct detrimental to the league.‚Äù  The statement specifically noted games against the Orlando Magic and the Miami Heat in which Utah sat Lauri Markkanen and Jaren Jackson Jr. in the fourth quarters.  The Jazz lost to Orlando, but beat Miami.
fullText:
On Thursday, the NBA announced just 30 minutes before the Utah Jazz‚Äôs home game against the Portland Trail Blazers that it was fining the Jazz $500,000 for ‚Äúconduct detrimental to the league.‚Äù

The statement specifically noted games against the Orlando Magic and the Miami Heat in which Utah sat Lauri Markkanen and Jaren Jackson Jr. in the fourth quarters. The Jazz lost to Orlando, but beat Miami.

The NBA implemented the Player Participation Policy at the start of the 2023-24 season. The policy lays out rules for teams regarding participation of the league‚Äôs star players, which is defined as any player named to an All-NBA team or named an NBA All-Star in any of the previous three seasons.

Markkanen and Jackson are the only players on the Jazz for whom that definition applies to.

One rule in the policy states, ‚ÄúTeams must refrain from any long-term shutdown (or near shutdown) whereby a star player ceases participating in games or begins to play a materially reduced role in circumstances affecting the integrity of the game.‚Äù

The Jazz won‚Äôt have to worry about Jackson‚Äôs minutes moving forward this season, as the team announced Thursday that he will likely be out for the remainder of the season due to a knee surgery to remove a benign tumor.

Utah head coach Will Hardy said he sat Markkanen against the Magic and Heat because Markkanen was on a minutes restriction, and Hardy said he‚Äôd continue to do so if instructed by the medical team.

‚ÄúSo if our medical team puts a minutes restriction on Lauri, I‚Äôll try to keep Lauri healthy,‚Äù Hardy said.

The Jazz were again without any of their star players in Thursday‚Äôs 135-119 loss to the Trail Blazers, as Keyonte George also continued to sit out due to an ankle sprain he sustained against the Magic.

Portland was without All-Star Deni Avdija.

The Jazz played tight and went into halftime with a 63-61 lead but fell apart in the third quarter as it‚Äôs done numerous times this year.

The Trail Blazers outscored Utah 40-23 in the third.

‚ÄúThe game got away from us in the third quarter, mostly because of fouling,‚Äù Hardy said. ‚ÄúThey shot 16 free throws in the quarter. When that happens, it‚Äôs also hard to get into a rhythm offensively because you‚Äôre playing against a set defense for most of the time.‚Äù

Utah did see some life in the fourth, especially from Svi Mykhailiuk. The veteran was out of the rotation for three straight games but came into Thursday‚Äôs contest and scored 14 points in just 17 minutes.

He shot 4 of 5 from behind the 3-point line and the Jazz opened the quarter outscoring Portland 22-10.

‚ÄúSvi‚Äôs been the ultimate pro his entire time with us,‚Äù Hardy said. ‚ÄúThere are times that he‚Äôs in the rotation, there‚Äôs times he‚Äôs been a starter, there‚Äôs times he‚Äôs been out of the rotation and he always handles himself with a ton of class.‚Äù

Despite the Jazz clawing back from a 15-point deficit, Portland ran away with it.

Brice Sensabaugh led the Jazz with 28 points, while Kyle Filipowski, Isaiah Collier and Ace Bailey all added 15 points.

Utah‚Äôs new two-way player, Blake Hinson, also saw his first minutes in Thursday‚Äôs loss and scored 11 points on 4 of 7 shooting in his debut.

title: Wrexham duo plot downfall of former club Ipswich
description: Nathan Broadhead and Kieffer Moore both helped Ipswich Town in their rise up the football pyramid but are now bidding to knock their former club out of the FA Cup with Wrexham.
fullText:
Kieffer Moore and Nathan Broadhead played key roles in Ipswich Town's rise up the football pyramid.

But the Welsh duo are now plotting the Tractor Boys' downfall as they bid to fire Wrexham into the fifth round of the FA Cup for the first time since 1996-97 by beating their former employers.

"I can't wait to see many close friends of mine that I spent two-and-a-half years with, I'm looking forward to seeing them, and hopefully we can beat them," Broadhead told BBC Radio Wales Sport.

While also showing sentiment towards those at Portman Road, forward Moore was equally ruthless.

"I love playing against my old sides and I love scoring against them too," he told BBC Match of the Day Wales.

Latest Wrexham news, analysis and fan views

Moore targeting Wrexham and Wales double

After joining Ipswich from Everton in January 2023, Broadhead netted eight goals in 19 league appearances to help fire the Tractor Boys to promotion from League One.

He scored 13 league goals in the 2023-24 campaign as Kieran McKenna's side gained promotion into the Premier League, ending the club's 22-year absence from the top-flight.

"They were in League One at the time and my ambition was to play in the Premier League with that club, and we did it," said Broadhead.

"It was really good for me and my career so I'm just thankful for that.

"We had the same team, near enough, from League One and everyone knew how each other played. It was a crazy few years, some of the best of my career to be fair."

Moore - who was also with Ipswich in 2017-18 - spent the latter half of the 2023-24 season alongside Broadhead at Portman Road, scoring seven goals as they clinched promotion to the top-flight.

"I can only speak highly about that club. Everything around that club is amazing," Moore said of Ipswich.

"I have very fond memories of the place, of course. Getting promoted to the Premier League was incredible. I'll look forward to seeing some of the guys."

Now bidding to haunt his former employers, Broadhead hopes to emulate his Ipswich success by guiding Wrexham into the Premier League.

Phil Parkinson's men sit sixth in the Championship, and having already beaten Premier League Nottingham Forest in this year's FA Cup, and Broadhead is hoping for more nights to remember in north Wales.

"It (Forest win) was some feeling. It just shows where we're at as a team, competing with teams and players like that," he explained.

Just eight days after their cup tussle, Wrexham and Ipswich meet again in the Championship, so there will be ample opportunity for Broadhead and Moore to become reacquainted with their former team-mates.

But the bigger picture always circles back to the main goal. A fourth consecutive Wrexham promotion.

"We're in a good position at the moment but there's a long way to go. The last 15 games are massive," said Broadhead.

Listen to Wrexham interviews, news and discussion on BBC Sounds

Five years of Hollywood - Wrexham's transformation

title: Draymond Green Slams Doris Burke Over Biased Reporting, Using Broadcasts to ‚ÄúTake Shots‚Äù at Him
description: Golden State Warriors‚Äô loss to the San Antonio Spurs on Wednesday would sting heavily, considering they were 16 points up in the third quarter. But their effort cannot be undermined either, with Draymond Green in particular, doing his absolute level best to contain Victor Wembanyama in the game.
fullText:
Golden State Warriors‚Äô loss to the San Antonio Spurs on Wednesday would sting heavily, considering they were 16 points up in the third quarter. But their effort cannot be undermined either, with Draymond Green in particular, doing his absolute level best to contain Victor Wembanyama in the game. The way the game was called, however, left the Warriors legend disappointed.

Green scored 17 points on the night, and his defense on Wembanyama limited him to 26. It was enough for the Spurs, but in the roughly the first half of the game, life was made difficult for the Frenchman. Amidst their physical tussle, though, Wembanyamatoo tried to stop Green by going that extra leg, and at one point, had his arms wrapped completely around him.

A fan pointed this out on social media platform threads, and called Doris Burke, who was commentator for the game, out. Green responded and didn‚Äôt hold back on his thoughts on her.

‚ÄúShe will always ignore things happening to me and only half mention the good. And take shots when they are available. Been that way for a while,‚Äù Green replied.

Green has many enemies in the league. Most of them are players who‚Äôve seen his ugly side when he resorts to fights on the court or reacts violently to relatively small incidents. Ask Rudy Gobert and Josef Nurkic. They may not admit it, but they would genuinely avoid altercations with Green.

This has not helped Green‚Äôs reputation among journalists and broadcasters. His ability is not in doubt, and people know how great a defender he can be. However, a chokehold on a multiple-time Defensive Player of the Year is something that becomes difficult to forget.

That said, commentary should not be biased either. Green has a right to be upset about the fact that Burke rarely says positive things about him, even when he is actually playing well. For instance, against the Spurs on Wednesday, it was one of his better nights of the 2025-26 season.

A small acknowledgment of that would not have hurt and may have prevented this online dig at Burke.

The post Draymond Green Slams Doris Burke Over Biased Reporting, Using Broadcasts to ‚ÄúTake Shots‚Äù at Him appeared first on The SportsRush.

title: Blue Jays predicted to sign Phillies' $20M reject, Silver Slugger winner after losing Kyle Tucker
description: This deal could be very beneficial after Anthony Santander's injury and missing out on Kyle Tucker.
fullText:
Blue Jays predicted to sign Phillies' $20M reject, Silver Slugger winner after losing Kyle Tucker originally appeared on The Sporting News. Add The Sporting News as a Preferred Source by clicking here.

The Toronto Blue Jays got off to a strong start this offseason, but ultimately missed out on several remaining big-name targets. Their biggest miss came when Kyle Tucker signed with the Los Angeles Dodgers.

‚ÄúKyle Tucker, the consensus best player available in free agency, agreed to join the Dodgers on Thursday, sources told ESPN, a little more than a month after star closer Edwin Diaz did the same. Tucker's deal is for four years at $240 million and includes opt-outs after the second and third seasons, sources told ESPN's Jeff Passan and Jesse Rogers,‚Äù ESPN‚Äôs Alden Gonzalez wrote.

The Blue Jays can still make a late addition, and one name to watch is Nick Castellanos. FanSided‚Äôs Mark Powell believes Castellanos will sign with Toronto after being released on Thursday.

‚ÄúOf those teams, I'd consider the Blue Jays favorites due to need alone. Toronto lost outfielder Anthony Santander to injury, as he's expected to miss 5-6 months after undergoing shoulder surgery,‚Äù Powell wrote.

While Castellanos isn‚Äôt the same type of player Tucker is, he would give Toronto a veteran option in right field. Castellanos was released by the Philadelphia Phillies on Thursday and will still be owed the remainder of his contract from Philadelphia.

‚ÄúThe Philadelphia Phillies released outfielder Nick Castellanos on Thursday after the team was unable to make a deal to trade him. Castellanos then revealed he was benched last season after bringing beer into the dugout during a game. The team wanted the situation resolved before its first full-squad workout at spring training, which is Monday,‚Äù ESPN wrote.

Castellanos would provide a powerful right-handed bat, though he won‚Äôt be as reliable defensively, as he is considered one of the weaker defenders in the game. Still, his offensive upside makes him an intriguing option for the Blue Jays.

Toronto is looking to add a veteran presence, and Castellanos brings that along with World Series experience ‚Äî exactly what the organization is hoping to recapture. A move like this could provide meaningful support to Toronto‚Äôs lineup.

title: Where to watch Canada vs. Switzerland men's hockey: Live stream, channel, time, TV schedule for 2026 Olympics game

fullText:
