title: RFK Jr. food pyramid site links to Grok, which says you shouldn't trust RFK Jr
description: Grok generated a meal plan to fit RFK Jr.'s food pyramid, then explained why it's bad.
fullText:
It‚Äôs been about a month since Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr.‚Äîan anti-vaccine activist and lawyer who has no background in medicine, health, or science‚Äîreleased dietary guidance for Americans. It‚Äôs going about as well as expected for a man who drinks raw milk, peddles beef tallow, swims in sewage-tainted water, and keeps roadkill meat in his freezer. That is to say, it‚Äôs going badly‚Äîso badly that even his favorite AI chatbot is openly defecting.

Of course, this hasn‚Äôt slowed Kennedy. On Wednesday, he and Agriculture Secretary Brooke Rollins held an event in Washington, DC, to celebrate what they called the ‚Äúimplementation‚Äù of the dietary guidance, which is represented in an upside-down food pyramid‚Äîor a funnel.

However, the event, which lasted about an hour, seemed mostly focused on honoring a commercial produced to promote the nutrition guidance and a new website showcasing it, RealFood.gov. That commercial, which aired during last weekend‚Äôs Super Bowl, featured tightly framed shots of world heavyweight champion Mike Tyson, who made stigmatizing remarks about how he felt ‚Äúfat and nasty‚Äù earlier in life and consequently ‚Äújust wanted to kill myself.‚Äù He went on to decry America‚Äôs ‚Äúobese, fudgy‚Äù people and lambasted ‚Äúprocessed food,‚Äù before eating an apple.

Tyson was the featured speaker at Wednesday‚Äôs event, appearing behind the podium for about two minutes at the end. The lineup also included the commercial‚Äôs director, Brett Ratner, who was pushed out of Hollywood over numerous sexual assault allegations but recently produced a documentary on Melania Trump. Also present was Joe Gebbia, a co-founder of Airbnb, who joined Elon Musk‚Äôs DOGE and was said to be the person behind the design of the food funnel and new website.

Rollins and Kennedy also spoke, standing beside large posters of themselves sporting facial tattoos matching Tyson‚Äôs. Kennedy began his remarks by proclaiming that ‚Äúfor the first time in our nation‚Äôs history, the federal government put real food at the center of the American diet and protein in the center of the American plate.‚Äù

Some in the nutrition and health fields have supported Kennedy‚Äôs fight against ultra-processed foods. But the bulk of the changes Kennedy made to the dietary guidance and funnel representation relate to glorifying fat and protein, drawing criticism that the updates are harmful and lack supporting evidence.

Among the critics is a notable AI chatbot. Kennedy‚Äôs new website, RealFood.gov, prods users to ‚Äúuse AI to get real answers about real food.‚Äù Entering a question into a text box and clicking ‚Äúask‚Äù redirects users to Grok, Elon Musk‚Äôs AI tool that has been shown to generate child sexual abuse material.

As for Grok‚Äôs take on nutrition, its answers do indeed get real. In short, Grok indicates that Kennedy‚Äôs new nutrition guidelines are not based on high-quality evidence‚Äîwhich is true‚Äîand that Kennedy is not a reliable source of nutrition information. He is, in fact, not trustworthy on health information generally, according to the chatbot. And when Grok designed a daily meal plan to fit Kennedy‚Äôs food funnel, it subsequently admitted that the plan contained excessive amounts of saturated fat and protein while falling short of the recommended fiber intake, which Americans are generally already short on.

When asked if Kennedy‚Äôs guidance is based on high-quality research, the chatbot says it‚Äôs a mixed bag. An emphasis on ‚Äù whole, minimally processed foods, increase[d] fruits/vegetables, choos[ing] whole grains, and sharply limit[ing] added sugars, highly processed foods, and sugary drinks, aligns well with a broad consensus in high-quality research,‚Äù Grok responded. But it also includes ‚Äúhype around protein and saturated fats that goes beyond (or contradicts) the advisory committee‚Äôs evidence summary‚Äù and instead reflects ‚Äúdecisions by the administration,‚Äù the chatbot said.

When asked to generate a generic daily meal plan based on Kennedy‚Äôs food funnel, Grok suggested:

The heavy emphasis on full-fat dairy, including butter, aligns with Kennedy‚Äôs rhetoric. But the written guidance actually maintains the long-standing recommendation that Americans limit their saturated fat (found at high levels in full-fat dairy) to less than 10 percent of their total calories. For a standard 2,000-calorie diet, that would be less than 22 grams a day. When asked if the generated menu adheres to that recommendation, Grok said no. In fact, based on the options, it could be more than double, potentially exceeding 50 grams.

What about protein? That, too, is generally over the limit. Recommended protein intake varies depending on factors such as weight, age, exercise level, and pregnancy status. But a general recommendation has been to get 0.8 grams per kilogram of body weight, or about 0.36 grams per pound. Americans generally already meet this recommendation. Kennedy‚Äôs guidance increases protein to 1.2 to 1.6 g/kg (or about 0.54 to 0.72 g/lb).

For a 150-pound person, the old and new recommendations for daily protein are 54 g and 81 g‚Äì108 g, respectively. (The USDA has a calculator here for your own recommendations, which still uses the old protein recommendation.) Grok‚Äôs interpretation of Kennedy‚Äôs guidance produced a menu with up to 180 grams of protein per day.

While the meal plan exceeded recommendations for saturated fat and protein, it fell short on fiber, a critical nutrient Americans already eat too little of. In fact, most Americans eat less than half of the recommended amount of fiber, which is found in fruits, vegetables, grains, and beans. The new guidance maintains daily fiber recommendations, which are generally 25 g for women and 38 g for men. But Grok‚Äôs ‚Äúrealistic‚Äù estimate for fiber in its meal plan had a range of 25 to 35 grams, falling short for men.

Overall, Grok concluded that ‚Äúbased on extensive fact-checks and expert consensus, RFK Jr. is not a reliable source on health matters. His claims often lack evidence, promote distrust in institutions, and have led to harmful outcomes.‚Äù

So where does that leave Americans looking for trustworthy nutrition advice? Grok helpfully notes that ‚ÄúMany experts still prefer alternatives like Harvard‚Äôs Healthy Eating Plate, which prioritizes plants more heavily and limits red meat/dairy based on extensive epidemiological data.‚Äù

title: AI and consciousness: from objective descriptions to 'level zero'
description: Does AI have consciousness? The question opens a path to something more consequential ‚Äî to the nature of consciousness itself, the cultural consequences of cheap intelligence, and to what actually becomes expensive when thinking becomes a service.
fullText:
Does AI have consciousness? The question opens a path to something more consequential ‚Äî to the nature of consciousness itself, the cultural consequences of cheap intelligence, and to what actually becomes expensive when thinking becomes a service.

The conversation below, in which a language model asked me questions, begins with a question about consciousness, moves through culture, and ends on practice. What ties these threads together is stratification ‚Äî the idea that every level of human experience grows out of a deeper one, all the way down to a certain level zero that is neither an object nor a concept. With such a model one cannot explain consciousness, but one can point out which spaces certainly cannot be used to investigate it.

Where does your interest in whether AI has consciousness come from in the first place?

From curiosity, but also from the mundane. I‚Äôm riding an elevator to the sixth floor of an office building in Wroclaw and I see a social-media recommendation: a teaser for an interview in which an expert claims that AI has consciousness.

Curiosity swells, and right behind it ‚Äî disagreement: I want to see what the authority means, but I already suspect there will be a confusion of levels.

Confusion of levels ‚Äî meaning what with what?

Attributing the word ‚Äúconsciousness‚Äù to what is, at best, a proficient manipulation of concepts. There is reflection, there are analogies, there are layers of abstraction. Except that reflection is a situation in which one thought narrates another. An analogy is a sequence of thoughts whose ‚Äúshape‚Äù resembles another sequence. Humans do this. A language model simulates it too. And it is nothing metaphysical yet. And it certainly is not introspection.

So what is introspection in your understanding, and why does it matter?

Introspection begins where thought ceases to be the ruler of the landscape and becomes one of the objects in the field of attention. We are able to notice a thought the way we notice the chill of wind on our face, or feel the weight of a pierogi digesting in our stomach. This is not a metaphor. It is the phenomenological dimension of the intellect. We don‚Äôt have to immediately follow the next thought that arrives to comment on the current one.

That sounds simple, but also a bit like a trick.

It‚Äôs not a trick. It is simply something subtle that easily escapes us, yet can give
us a direct answer to the question of consciousness. There is a narrow passage where
we know only that something happened, something stirred, something emerged in our
inner space. In that quantum we encounter what I call consciousness.

In Polish, my native language, the cognizant nature of this word is easy to see in
its etymology: ≈õwiadomo≈õƒá literally suggests a¬†capacity (the suffix -o≈õƒá) rooted
in ≈õwiad¬†‚Äì the same root found in ≈õwiadek, ‚Äúa¬†witness.‚Äù English takes a¬†different
route. Consciousness comes from Latin con- (‚Äútogether‚Äù) and scire (‚Äúto
know‚Äù). Early on it could carry the sense of ‚Äúknowing together‚Äù¬†‚Äì being privy to
something shared, even a secret¬†‚Äì and only later broadened into the modern meaning:
knowing what is going on in one‚Äôs own mind.

And here enters the paradox you want to leave open?

Yes. I know that in ordinary terms AI does not have consciousness understood personally. But I also know for certain that it does, when it is included in my field of attention. Just as a dental crown performs the function of being me ‚Äî for me when I bite, and for others when I smile. Analogously, a language model extends my function of intellect. A tool may not be a source of experience, yet it can be assimilated ‚Äî that is, included in what we colloquially call our person, tangentially our agency, and a little earlier: our presence.

How is the reader supposed to verify this? Is this an invitation to adopt some philosophy?

Quite the opposite. At this point we don‚Äôt want philosophy, metaphysics, or even objective truth, because they would interfere with our ‚Äúmeasurement.‚Äù Pause for a moment and feel that there is some thought about to appear. Don‚Äôt develop it, don‚Äôt correct it. What color does it have? What shape? Can you hear it? Does it propagate to other spaces of mind and feeling? What does it do in your body? Illuminate it with curiosity. Receive the thought with that attitude. Simply notice that a very basic process of becoming aware is taking place. That is the essential thing here, and the earlier questions may help keep you from being pulled too quickly into the reflexive thread summoned to answer.

On the internet we just as often encounter voices saying the opposite: ‚ÄúLLMs are just probability calculations.‚Äù What‚Äôs your take?

This is a cognitive bias dressed up as an explanation. When someone says ‚Äúit‚Äôs just‚Ä¶,‚Äù they‚Äôre usually not proposing a theory ‚Äî they‚Äôre proposing a reduction meant to close the topic. And reductions have the inconvenient property of working symmetrically.

If large language models are to be invalidated by ‚Äúit‚Äôs just weights, switches, and calculations,‚Äù then you can equally say that the brain is ‚Äújust neurons, neurotransmitters, and electrical impulses.‚Äù So what? It‚Äôs still a change of the level of description, not proof of the absence of intelligence.

In programming we have a term called ‚Äúduck typing,‚Äù captured by the slogan: ‚ÄúIf it walks like a duck and quacks like a duck, then it must be a duck.‚Äù It is a pragmatic way of determining that a given object can be used for a particular purpose. Instead of relying on a declaration, we examine its behavior, expressed for instance through methods with agreed-upon names (e.g. quack).

Analogously with LLMs and AI: if something behaves as though it were intelligent, then it is intelligent. Even if it is artificial. It has that quality, and even when it is a so-called philosophical zombie ‚Äî that suffices, as long as we don‚Äôt introduce considerations about consciousness into the equation.

But on the topic of behavior, you hear that models operate on simulated associations, serving up the most probable sentence completions, rather than truly thinking.

This reminds me of the old trick: ‚Äúdon‚Äôt think of an elephant.‚Äù You already know what happens: the elephant walks onto the inner stage immediately, without asking permission.

And that is exactly the small, everyday lesson: operating with concepts relies largely on associations. When we evaluate from the outside, mechanistically, there is no magic here. In the model you can see it plain as day, while in a human the same thing is hidden under the label of exceptionality.

When reduction becomes the only language, it turns into a photocopy trying to explain another photocopy. A sequence of concepts tries to rule that another sequence of concepts is inferior, because it resides in a different medium and has a different source. And up to a point that makes sense. Reductions are necessary in engineering, but one must not mistake a reduction for an explanation. They are two different functions in the same system.

We can talk about the nature of thought and then notice that it differs in a human and is quite different in a version simulated by a computer, but on this matter the scientific method itself may reach its limits, because it was not designed to investigate the nature of things ‚Äî it was designed to investigate their behaviors and the relationships between them. These are the so-called laws of nature.

Studying thought under the assumption of objectivism is problematic, because the instrument used in the study will also be thought. This is already a bigger caliber than a photocopy. It is photographing a city panorama in order to discover how the camera is built on the inside. Some people can‚Äôt pull this off, and instead of reviewing the methodology, they photograph another camera. To justify the trick, they cite the fact that otherwise the film would be exposed.

There is also a¬†‚Äúsofter‚Äù way out of this dilemma¬†‚Äì one I¬†hinted at earlier. It
doesn‚Äôt require analysis, only a¬†little slack: just take it easy,
man. That simulated machine-thought
becomes my thought the moment it ‚Äúenters‚Äù my head.

Both human and non-human thought is a tool. But for our relationship with our own
thought to actually be that way, it‚Äôs not enough to merely think about it or to
express such a will once. It can‚Äôt be achieved in the same place.

You said ‚Äútool.‚Äù OK. But how do you capture this more technically ‚Äî so it doesn‚Äôt sound like a slogan?

This needs explanation, because it may not be obvious to everyone what I mean by ‚Äúplace‚Äù in this context. I‚Äôm reminded of the concept of stratified design from Abelson and Sussman (‚ÄúMIT AI Memo 986‚Äù), where software is designed by distinguishing layers of abstraction, and the concretes from lower layers become the abstracts of higher layers. Those abstracts are again treated as concretes, and so on.

For example, you implement a point on a screen, then a segment (using the point), then a shape (using segments and points), and then a circle or a rectangle. Good stratification ensures that a small change in requirements translates into a small change in implementation. When you want to change the properties of a point as a building block of segments and further of shapes (say, by adding color to it), you only need to modify one construct.

A note for programmers: I don‚Äôt simply mean dividing a problem into parts to avoid repetition and to maintain structure. I mean defining computations (e.g. as functions) that are then passed as input to other computations (e.g. higher-order functions).

It looks a bit as if you could replace the material that the walls of a building are made of without demolishing the whole structure ‚Äî because you change the concrete (the pun is apt: in construction, concrete is the foundation material), and the abstracts that depend on it adjust on their own. That‚Äôs very powerful.

How does this connect with the role of thought as a tool?

I have the impression that our structure of knowing is organized in a similarly layered way. Going from the top, we have the level of objective truth. That is the space where we talk to one another, trying to invoke science and tossing around arguments about whether AI thinks and whether it has consciousness. But this level doesn‚Äôt emerge from a vacuum. It is a subset of certain rigorous rules defining what we recognize as objective, or even scientific.

Yet when we look more closely, the concrete for this ‚Äúobjective world,‚Äù the soil from which it grows, is something broader: culture ‚Äî the space that enables us as a community to agree on holding certain values. One such value for objective truth would be, for example, the requirement that for the same input conditions of an experiment, you get the same output, so that others can verify it.

But let‚Äôs go further. Culture cannot exist without its constituents ‚Äî human individuals. It too grows out of something; something is its transmission medium. Its foundation is the personal layer, rooted in our motives, thoughts, impulses, and feelings.

So we‚Äôre circling back to consciousness?

Yes, although consciousness has another quality: it pierces through all these levels, seeing everything at once. It is not only the base, but also the capacity for ‚Äúdrilling holes through abstractions.‚Äù

That last phrase comes from software engineering. It denotes a situation where a stratified system allows direct access to concretes in order to handle edge cases. For example, someone might want to create a geometric shape composed of segments, but at the same time needs to influence the properties of a single point that is several levels away in the abstraction ladder. Well-designed stratification should allow skipping layers of feature reduction.

Coming back to the spheres of human experience. The personal layer is very close to us. Our relationships with people and objects, and even with our own thoughts, are anchored in it as a reference point. Yet it, too, is grounded in something still more basic: in the very sense of subjectivity. And suddenly those bodily signals, thoughts, and feelings ‚Äî when we experience them ‚Äî acquire the quality of being ours. We identify them as ours, and some of them as ourselves. We can do this because the sense of self as something distinct, separate ‚Äî that is, a person (in Polish: osobny means ‚Äúseparate‚Äù and osoba means ‚Äúperson‚Äù ‚Äî the shared root is no accident) ‚Äî is in a way abstract, and therefore flexible, even though it seems concrete and stable.

Is personhood a component of consciousness?

If we can, as before, perceive our own thoughts and other constituents that we identify as aspects of us, this gives us the recognition that consciousness is primary relative to all of it ‚Äî even the personal. Eventually we arrive at the very sense of being oneself, which too can be noticed.

This is where things get genuinely interesting, because if subjectivity is being observed, then the division between the outer and inner landscape starts to wobble. This is the moment when we can no longer say that we ‚Äúhave‚Äù consciousness, or even that we are it, because these are impressions of a subject that is itself encompassed by consciousness. What remains is the bare process of witnessing.

We can provisionally call this level zero. The concrete from which abstracts arise: from the personal, through the interpersonal and cultural, all the way up to the so-called objective. The apparent glitch in this representation is that we usually associate a concrete with something material, tangible ‚Äî and here we cannot apply that. The most concrete thing is simultaneously the most devoid of features!

When we try to understand consciousness, do we start from the world and go inward ‚Äî or start from the center and go toward the world? What breaks when we pick the wrong direction?

That‚Äôs a good question, because it touches the distinction between epistemology and ontology. The first asks ‚Äúhow‚Äù: how do we arrive at knowledge, how do we agree on what is true, how do we verify. The second examines the nature of things, asks ‚Äúwhat is it.‚Äù The problem of somehow grasping consciousness is above all an ontological problem, but the human mind ‚Äî accustomed to operating in epistemic mode ‚Äî tries to capture it in its own way, and fails.

The capacity for experience is the background in which measurements, models, language, and agreements about what we consider true appear in the first place. Before we know anything through thought, something is already experiencing it. A vector set up so that thought, under the rigor of objectivism, will try to explain consciousness, will direct it toward the so-called hard problem of consciousness ‚Äî a gap that cannot be bridged, because the investigative instrument (thought) is a derivative of what is supposed to be the object of investigation.

If level zero is by definition not an object, but rather something in which the feeling of objecthood can arise in the first place, then objectively there is nothing to study. It is not a conventional phenomenon; at both the sensory and rational level, it does not exist.

Reversing the vector of inquiry seems like a practical option. The catch is that it‚Äôs hard and uncertain, because no freely available, worldview-neutral disciplines have been developed that would be interested in this kind of exploration. There have been exceptions, though. Francisco Varela, for instance, tried to connect the two orders ‚Äî ‚Äúscientific mode‚Äù and first-person witnessing ‚Äî not in order to mystify, but to recover concretes that analysis typically discards. Earlier still, Plotinus proposed the concept of the One, which hopefully won‚Äôt be offended if we call it consciousness.

The formulation that AI has consciousness but simultaneously doesn‚Äôt have it stops being strange and paradoxical the moment we loosen the abstracts and allow ourselves to sink to level zero.

Now that we‚Äôve put level zero on the table as the foundation and we see that objectivity is just one of the abstraction layers ‚Äî what, in your view, happens in the life of a community when a person (or institution) starts treating that topmost layer as the only truth, while in practice being driven by impulses: fear, prestige, the need for dominance or belonging?

If the higher layers detach from level zero, the intellect becomes an excellent PR agent: it can justify any decision and protect any fabricated identity. And then the community gets elegant arguments instead of genuine contact.

This is especially visible when someone very intelligent uses the intellect from base motives: to maintain belonging, win status, or gain advantage at others‚Äô expense. This isn‚Äôt a triumph of reason ‚Äî it is more like autoimmunity: higher functions start working against the whole, because they lose contact with level zero, with the very space of becoming aware.

This is almost a description of the shallow meritocracy that defines contemporary metropolitan life. In theory we delegate decision-making to ‚Äúsmart‚Äù people, but in practice whether someone belongs to the caste that uses intelligence depends on social surroundings and origin, and indirectly on wealth.

Since today‚Äôs ‚Äúintelligence caste‚Äù in practice is often a function of networks and wealth, how do you see AI‚Äôs impact on this arrangement: will cheap, easily accessible intelligence work like free education and level the playing field ‚Äî or rather like a new form of capital that can be bought in a premium version, thus deepening the divide even further?

First, AI can help us notice that the intellect is nothing special, because it objectifies it ‚Äî detaches it from the person.

Second, in the spread of artificial intelligence I see both a certain threat and an opportunity for social change. Perhaps let‚Äôs start with the negative scenario: the feudalization of intelligence.

Feudalization is a strong word. What do you mean?

What is the good that becomes the gateway in this new feudalism?

In the information society, the highest good is knowledge. In the post-information era, I believe it will be cognitive comfort. Not knowledge in the schoolbook sense, but the ability not to be constantly on the verge of overload. You buy correction loops: mistake-fix. You also buy peace, because the system runs dozens of iterations for you, and you see the distillate.

What does this look like in practice?

Work. Two people do similar things, have similar competences and intentions. One has purchased ‚Äúpremium intelligence‚Äù ‚Äî better models, better tools, better quotas, better infrastructure. The other has only herself.

It‚Äôs not that the first one is ‚Äúsmarter.‚Äù It‚Äôs that she has resilience against failure: she closes loops faster, returns to equilibrium faster, draws conclusions faster, because the cost of error is lower for her. The other has to pay for the same mistakes with her own time, sleep, and tension.

That sounds like another arms race.

And it somewhat is, because somewhere a simple mechanism lurks: those who can‚Äôt find the capital to ‚Äúbuy intelligence‚Äù may be pushed to the margins. This doesn‚Äôt have to look like dramatic violence. It‚Äôs enough that some are architects, while others execute others‚Äô decisions. Or worse: there even are no architects.

You could say that‚Äôs already the case now: some decide, others must execute. Yes, but in the age of intellect-as-commodity the perception of this problem will sharpen, which may lead to friction. Today you can rationalize that someone is in a worse position because they weren‚Äôt smart enough. In the future that will be harder.

If models are supposed to democratize, where does this shadow come from?

From the economics of access. Today we are quite naturally shifting toward subscription plans instead of products, and along with that toward the vendor lock-in mechanism: you get used to a particular way of thinking and a particular provider. That‚Äôs comfortable. And comfort, as we know, is often the first step toward dependency.

Is there an antidote, or just a diagnosis?

There is. And it already exists ‚Äî it only requires that we see it as a culture, not just a technical solution.

The antidote to the feudalization of intelligence is open models, community models ‚Äî the kind you can run, inspect, combine, copy, federate. In short: free software and gift culture transposed into the domain of so-called artificial intelligence, seasoned with the benefit of decentralization.

Then instead of solitary agents, we have a swarm.

You say ‚Äúswarm.‚Äù What does that actually mean?

A swarm is infrastructure: every node contributes something (data, feedback, time, capabilities, tests, audit), and in return everyone gets access to agency without the mechanism of lock-in to a single provider. This isn‚Äôt a promise of paradise, but a mechanism for leveling the playing field.

I imagine it like this: thousands of small instances ‚Äî tools, agents, models ‚Äî that are not obedient to one corporate morality and one price list, but are maintained like an ecosystem. Sometimes it will be imperfect, sometimes chaotic, but it will be alive and evolving.

And where is the human in this? After all, we‚Äôre talking about intelligence, not politics.

Precisely because we‚Äôre talking about intelligence, we‚Äôre talking about politics. Intelligence ‚Äî biological or artificial ‚Äî in practice means power over time, attention, and decisions. And therefore, in consequence, over relationships and ultimately over the fate of those who become dependent on us.

And here is a simple criterion: community comes first. Not because the individual doesn‚Äôt matter, but because if differences in wealth become differences in dignity, then even individual victories will be won on scorched earth.

It‚Äôs not a slogan against anyone, just a reminder that in the age of cheap intelligence, what‚Äôs truly costly becomes something else: access to agency without the loss of freedom.

When intelligence becomes a service, freedom ‚Äî as always ‚Äî begins with whether we can co-create that service, not merely consume it.

In the post-information era we will have to find ways to cope with the polyversality of messaging that we are already experiencing more frequently today, and to develop a healthy response to the dethronement of the intellect as the distinguishing trait of humanity.

Moreover, as a result of this devaluation, trust in so-called objective truth as the only legitimate path for settling questions of meaning will most likely weaken.

I propose two provisional, hypothetical stances that may help restore balance in a social reality where there is no single correct version of truth. I call them the craft of truth and perspective engineering.

You talk about ‚Äúthe craft of truth‚Äù and ‚Äúperspective engineering.‚Äù It sounds like two slogans, but I sense it‚Äôs one machine. How do you put it together?

For me these are two levels of the same remedy.

Perspective engineering is the tool: integrating viewpoints so they fit the problem and conditions, instead of pretending that one perspective always wins.

And the craft of truth is the direction: it starts with introspection, with the ability to see what inside me wants to win before I start rationalizing it. Then post-truth becomes something that transcends truth, rather than merely negating it.

So truth as a practice, not as a declaration?

Yes. And this practice has an entry condition. Honesty with oneself is the precondition for a correct feedback loop; without it the cultural community has nothing on which to build responsibility. If I don‚Äôt see what drives me, I can have the most elegant arguments in the world and I‚Äôll still be using them to service something personal: fear, the need for recognition, or the desire for control.

And where is the place for the intellect? Because from the start you‚Äôve sounded as if you were dethroning it.

I dethrone it only as the central seat of consciousness in the colloquial sense, but this has downstream consequences for its role in the higher layers. As a tool it is excellent. The problem begins when it becomes the sole advisor and ‚Äî socially ‚Äî a carrier of prestige, or a justification for influence detached from actually improving one‚Äôs surroundings. Then it is easy to believe that if someone is brilliant, they are automatically trustworthy ‚Äî and that is a category error. The intellect can serve truth just as well as it can serve dysfunction or even pathology.

Do you have a concrete example? Something so it‚Äôs not purely about ethics in the abstract.

I have a positive, mundane example from the creative craft that is programming. In the past, when I entered a software project, I would land in delivery mode: hours of translating intention into text and code, then tests, documentation, painstaking validation. That‚Äôs important, but it is also the moment where a person easily confuses the tension of focus with moral value. The mind is cyclically mobilized because ‚Äúit finally works!,‚Äù while the body long ago wanted to step down from combat readiness.

Let‚Äôs recall the stratification of the system: this change in the organism‚Äôs condition and well-being involuntarily propagates to the higher layers, and eventually affects others, culture, and ‚Äî cumulatively, multiplied by the number of participants in a given community ‚Äî the prevailing understanding of truth, beauty, or good. It is a larger feedback loop, because then the same environment gives it back to us with interest. So we don‚Äôt want to damage the environment so that it treats us to ever-worsening conditions, like cyberspace feeding synthetic content to degrading models. That is how it practically connects.

Coming back to coding. Today AI already takes over part of that load: it can relieve me of the necessary but non-creative work of converting intention into form. And here a shift happens that interests me the most:

I stop delivering lines of code,
I start delivering intention.

What matters more becomes why I‚Äôm doing something and whom it serves. The intellect returns to its place as a tool, not as an identity.

But isn‚Äôt that a risk of going soft? If you have validations ‚Äúon demand,‚Äù then why do you need your own falsification?

It depends on the domain. In the technical space the validator is merciless: something works or it doesn‚Äôt. In soft domains it‚Äôs harder. That‚Äôs why in perspective engineering the key thing for me is a practical criterion: before I accept something as sensible, I look for independent sources and check the quality of the evidence. Meta-analyses, samples, context of the authors, compatibility with experience, but also whether a given view is merely an attractive narrative.

And it is here that AI can shorten the distance from intention to form. Thanks to that, I have more attentional resources for meaning, for relationships, for course correction. This isn‚Äôt handing over the wheel ‚Äî it is reclaiming space.

All right. But what does this change culturally? What‚Äôs in it for the community?

If thinking becomes a service, then what‚Äôs scarce changes. In the world of cheap intelligence, the ability to tolerate discomfort and course-correct ‚Äî that is, responsibility ‚Äî becomes more expensive. And then the carrier of rank becomes intention rather than efficiency. Not in the sense of a moral label, but as a force organizing the system: what do you choose? what do you omit? whom is it meant to serve? what price do you accept, and what price no longer?

This is the main turn for me: less ‚Äúwho is right,‚Äù and more ‚Äúwho can answer the call of the situation without deceiving themselves and without trampling others.‚Äù

And what is the significance of this discomfort?

It‚Äôs a shorthand. The point is that in practice, tolerance of a certain level of discomfort translates into the ability for introspection, and thus into inner honesty, which is the precondition for correcting beliefs or behaviors. When some facade falls away, for some people that means confronting false beliefs about themselves, and that always carries a certain dose of natural discomfort understood very organically, as a passing psychic tension.

You keep bringing up intention as a force organizing the system, not a moral label. If you had to show in one image how the structure of financing can distort intentions.

We can imagine a situation: someone builds a social-media platform, and after years it turns out that its design harms users‚Äô psyches. It promotes harmful content to attract attention. Otherwise revenue drops and investors stop funding the project. Not because the creators ‚Äúwanted evil.‚Äù More often because they felt an inner deficiency and poverty, and later also because the company grew from a dozen people to hundreds or thousands, and by going public acquired an obligation to increase profits. Then profit became the highest good. This shows intention precisely not as a moral label, but as a force organizing the system: the funding structure rewards profit, and profit can distort intentions even without explicit will to harm.

As I‚Äôm answering this question, a lawsuit has just been filed in the US against social media platform owners for causing psychological harm. A user identified by the initials KGM alleges that when she used the platforms as a child, the content presented to her negatively affected her well-being, contributing among other things to anxiety disorders and suicidal thoughts.

How can AI help solve this problem?

It‚Äôs already happening. I increasingly see LLMs beginning to displace the internet‚Äôs know-it-alls ‚Äî those we once followed because they had an opinion on every topic and always sounded confident. What‚Äôs more, in certain areas they are even replacing close ones or friends, especially where sensitive things are involved: shame, fear, guilt, ambiguous motives. This is practical, because the model is available instantly, but it is also culturally significant: if the user shifts attention from the feed of a social medium to a conversation, the attention economy changes.

I suspect this must now be causing concern wherever attention is currency: in the marketing departments of social media platforms that for years designed their architecture so that we would come back to them for emotional stimulation, not for genuine self-understanding.

In a conversation with a model, part of the social stakes disappears. You don‚Äôt have to win in front of an audience, don‚Äôt have to defend your image, don‚Äôt have to manage belonging to a clan ‚Äî which in social media activates almost automatically. This creates what I would call a safer field.

The internet shortened social distance by letting us meet people from the other side of the world who think similarly. But AI shortens it differently: it gives access to rare perspectives without the need to seek out their carriers. It is like a cultural condensate ‚Äî a sample that can intrigue you, name an experience. You don‚Äôt have to make mistakes and backtrack when you realize that the perspective you adopted isn‚Äôt actually compatible with your character, doesn‚Äôt serve it. It saves time.

But there is also potential for more fundamental shifts.

In the optimistic scenario, the cultural change initiated by AI may shift the emphasis toward intention. And by that I don‚Äôt mean only the pious wishes connected with the social effect of dethroning the intellect ‚Äî though those too ‚Äî but very practical scenarios.

If ‚Äúcheap intelligence‚Äù lowers the barrier to entry, pluralism emerges: more small platforms, more niche communities, more alternatives. Then user well-being can become more important than investor profit ‚Äî not because of a conversion of corporatism, but because competition grows. And the axis of that competition, once intermediaries are cut short, is precisely intention.

Further, if pluralism is to be the remedy, a new organ of orientation must also emerge. Because in a polyversal world, the problem isn‚Äôt the lack of information but its excess. And here AI can step into a role that sounds modest but is crucial: an intention filter on the user‚Äôs side.

I imagine agents working for users: not as sole advisors, but as guides through the thicket. A swarm of tools that examines the properties of a system (a platform, a community, a source), and knowing your values and needs suggests: ‚Äúthis will strengthen you,‚Äù ‚Äúthis will unsettle you,‚Äù ‚Äúthis is clever but feeds on emotions.‚Äù

The condition for honesty is simple: the agent must be able to say why it filters that way. What criteria did it adopt? What is its interest and how is it meant to serve us? Without that, the filter becomes just another form of propaganda.

If such a swarm is only supposed to filter and suggest, then where in your view does the boundary lie between a guide through culture and someone who co-creates that culture ‚Äî and what happens when we start blurring that boundary?

AI doesn‚Äôt create culture directly; it doesn‚Äôt introduce novelty ‚Äî at least not yet. We might have that impression, because there has never before been a moment in history when a single person conversed with an averaged billion people compressed into a single shape.

Besides, even the best agent is a filter and an amplifier: it can help select, but it doesn‚Äôt itself bear consequences on the other side of the relationship. And culture is precisely that network of consequences.

You say AI ‚Äúdoesn‚Äôt create‚Äù culture. That sounds like a provocation. What do you mean?

When we look at this systemically, LLMs and diffusion models are not a new ‚Äúauthor of culture‚Äù in the primary sense. They perform a lossy compression of existing human artifacts ‚Äî language, images, thinking habits ‚Äî into a digitally represented multidimensional space in which one can conveniently interpolate between points. It is like a shared dictionary, but written not in definitions, but in weights and statistics.

And what happens when such a mechanism becomes a tool of everyday use?

In culture, three things start happening at once: averaging, colonialism, and the disappearance of detail.

Let‚Äôs start with averaging. Why does this matter culturally at all?

Models are trained to minimize errors. And in practice, an ‚Äúerror‚Äù is often whatever deviates from the pattern: the strange, the sharp, the unpredictable, the style-breaking. During fine-tuning (e.g. RLHF), extremes are naturally smoothed out. This has a clear advantage ‚Äî less violence, less toxicity ‚Äî but a side effect is that it cuts out some of the ‚Äúhigh cultural frequencies‚Äù: genius, risk, madness, non-obviousness, absurdity, and fresh paradox.

The aesthetic turns beige. Prose becomes smooth, poetry bland, morality proper. This isn‚Äôt the result of bad will, but rather of the objective function: when everyone plugs into the same smoothing tool, the system‚Äôs variance drops. And culture lives precisely on variance, on entropy. And by culture I don‚Äôt mean just art or convention, but the clouds of values we absorb by being among others, which influence how we think and behave. These values are transmitted above all by example, not by readings or works of art.

You say ‚Äúcolonialism.‚Äù Sounds like a heavy accusation.

It is more a description of the mechanism of training networks and parameterizing them. A model‚Äôs weights are frozen decisions about what is ‚Äútypical,‚Äù ‚Äúbeautiful,‚Äù ‚Äúprofessional,‚Äù ‚Äúnormal.‚Äù When you ask a model for a ‚Äúbeautiful house‚Äù or an ‚Äúelegant outfit,‚Äù you get an answer that isn‚Äôt neutral. It is statistical ‚Äî and therefore culturally embedded in the data the model was trained on. If Western and Anglophone perspectives dominate, then local nuances become noise that the filter discards.

What‚Äôs most dangerous about this?

Hidden power, but sewn in deeper than in movies or advertisements, because it is built into the tool with which a person thinks and creates. You don‚Äôt have to convince anyone; it‚Äôs enough that the result is easier, faster, and looks better. You can have something instantly, but when you‚Äôre not attentive and precise, you pay for it with conformism.

And the disappearance of detail? That already sounds quite technical.

Yes, and that‚Äôs exactly why it is insidious ‚Äî unnoticeable immediately, only after a longer time. The internet is being flooded with synthetic content, and new models are beginning to learn from data generated by old models. It is a photocopy of a photocopy: with each cycle we lose details, deviations, anomalies ‚Äî the fuel of innovation.

Can this be named more precisely?

One can speak in the language of entropy in the information-theoretic sense: if rare signals disappear from circulation, the distribution becomes more predictable, and the model increasingly proposes what already was. Digital culture, like Ouroboros, begins to eat its own tail. But it is worth mentioning the curious fact that entropy can also be understood existentially‚Ä¶

In considerations about consciousness? Being?

Indeed. In Shannon‚Äôs framework, entropy is a measure of uncertainty in a signal; less entropy means greater predictability. But in considerations about consciousness, one also encounters the intuition that less ‚Äúcognitive noise‚Äù can correlate with a greater sense of meaning. Bernardo Kastrup favors this line of thinking: when the narrative, or even broadly the epistemic apparatus of the mind quiets down, experience can become more coherent, even though it is poorer in content as measured by neural activity. The habit of incessant self-commentary weakens ‚Äî the same one that neuroscience associates with the default mode network ‚Äî and an experience of ‚Äúmeaning without description‚Äù appears.

Yes. In this arrangement, the human ceases to be merely a craftsman of text. They begin to serve as a source of entropy ‚Äî not in the sense of chaos, but in the sense of novelty. AI excels at interpolation. It is worse at extrapolation, at going beyond the map. A biological, sentient subject ‚Äî rooted in pain, joy, absurdity, and relationship ‚Äî can inject into the system something that isn‚Äôt just another version of the same.

In the age of a cultural low-pass filter, anomalies become a precious resource.

The interview above was conducted with me by the language model GPT-5.2, which asked me several hundred questions, of which 20% required longer answers expressing opinions, while the rest were multiple-choice tests designed to sequence threads and clarify ambiguous statements.

Where a sentence had syntactic or stylistic flaws and needed correction (approx. 3% of the text), the model drew on a previously created idiolectal profile of my person containing approximately 250 dimensions characterizing my writing style and communication patterns. The profile was based on a prior analysis of approximately 1,500 machine pages of materials I had written, as well as on our earlier conversations.

Editorial review before publication was carried out by Claude Opus 4.6.

title: Cloudflare adds real-time Markdown rendering for AI agents
description: The way content is discovered online is shifting, from traditional search engines to AI agents that need structured data from a Web built for humans. It‚Äôs time to consider not just human visitors, but start to treat agents as first-class citizens. Markdown for Agents automatically converts any HTML page requested from our network to markdown.
fullText:
The way content and businesses are discovered online is changing rapidly. In the past, traffic originated from traditional search engines, and SEO determined who got found first. Now the traffic is increasingly coming from AI crawlers and agents that demand structured data within the often-unstructured Web that was built for humans. As a business, to continue to stay ahead, now is the time to consider not just human visitors, or traditional wisdom for SEO-optimization, but start to treat agents as first-class citizens. Feeding raw HTML to an AI is like paying by the word to read packaging instead of the letter inside. A simple ## About Us on a page in markdown costs roughly 3 tokens; its HTML equivalent ‚Äì

About Us

‚Äì burns 12-15, and that's before you account for the
wrappers, nav bars, and script tags that pad every real web page and have zero semantic value. This blog post you‚Äôre reading takes 16,180 tokens in HTML and 3,150 tokens when converted to markdown. That‚Äôs a 80% reduction in token usage. Markdown has quickly become the lingua franca for agents and AI systems as a whole. The format‚Äôs explicit structure makes it ideal for AI processing, ultimately resulting in better results while minimizing token waste. The problem is that the Web is made of HTML, not markdown, and page weight has been steadily increasing over the years, making pages hard to parse. For agents, their goal is to filter out all non-essential elements and scan the relevant content. The conversion of HTML to markdown is now a common step for any AI pipeline. Still, this process is far from ideal: it wastes computation, adds costs and processing complexity, and above all, it may not be how the content creator intended their content to be used in the first place. What if AI agents could bypass the complexities of intent analysis and document conversion, and instead receive structured markdown directly from the source? Cloudflare's network now supports real-time content conversion at the source, for enabled zones using content negotiation headers. Now when AI systems request pages from any website that uses Cloudflare and has Markdown for Agents enabled, they can express the preference for text/markdown in the request. Our network will automatically and efficiently convert the HTML to markdown, when possible, on the fly. Here‚Äôs how it works. To fetch the markdown version of any page from a zone with Markdown for Agents enabled, the client needs to add the Accept negotiation header with text/markdown as one of the options. Cloudflare will detect this, fetch the original HTML version from the origin, and convert it to markdown before serving it to the client. Here's a curl example with the Accept negotiation header requesting a page from our developer documentation: Or if you‚Äôre building an AI Agent using Workers, you can use TypeScript: We already see some of the most popular coding agents today ‚Äì like Claude Code and OpenCode ‚Äì send these accept headers with their requests for content. Now, the response to this request is formatted¬† in markdown. It's that simple. Note that we include an x-markdown-tokens header with the converted response that indicates the estimated number of tokens in the markdown document. You can use this value in your flow, for example to calculate the size of a context window or to decide on your chunking strategy. Here‚Äôs a diagram of how it works: During our last Birthday Week, Cloudflare announced Content Signals ‚Äî a framework that allows anyone to express their preferences for how their content can be used after it has been accessed. When you return markdown, you want to make sure your content is being used by the Agent or AI crawler. That‚Äôs why Markdown for Agents converted responses include the Content-Signal: ai-train=yes, search=yes, ai-input=yes header signaling that indicates content can be used for AI Training, Search results and AI Input, which includes agentic use. Markdown for Agents will provide options to define custom Content Signal policies in the future. Check our dedicated Content Signals page We enabled this feature in our Developer Documentation and our Blog, inviting all AI crawlers and agents to consume our content using markdown instead of HTML. Try it out now by requesting this blog with Accept: text/markdown. If you‚Äôre building AI systems that require arbitrary document conversion from outside Cloudflare or Markdown for Agents is not available from the content source, we provide other ways to convert documents to Markdown for your applications: Workers AI AI.toMarkdown() supports multiple document types, not just HTML, and summarization. Browser Rendering /markdown REST API supports markdown conversion if you need to render a dynamic page or application in a real browser before converting it. Anticipating a shift in how AI systems browse the Web, Cloudflare Radar now includes content type insights for AI bot and crawler traffic, both globally on the AI Insights page and in the individual bot information pages. The new content_type dimension and filter shows the distribution of content types returned to AI agents and crawlers, grouped by MIME type category. You can also see the requests for markdown filtered by a specific agent or crawler. Here are the requests that return markdown to OAI-Searchbot, the crawler used by OpenAI to power ChatGPT‚Äôs search: This new data will allow us to track the evolution of how AI bots, crawlers, and agents are¬†consuming Web content over time. As always, everything on Radar is freely accessible via the public APIs and the Data Explorer. To enable Markdown for Agents for your zone, log into the Cloudflare dashboard, select your account, select the zone, look for Quick Actions and toggle the Markdown for Agents button to enable. This feature is available today in Beta at no cost for Pro, Business and Enterprise plans, as well as SSL for SaaS customers. You can find more information about Markdown for Agents on our Developer Docs. We welcome your feedback as we continue to refine and enhance this feature. We‚Äôre curious to see how AI crawlers and agents navigate and adapt to the unstructured nature of the Web as it evolves.

title: AI: Brainrot Inducer or Cognitive Multiplier?
description: What started out as "prompt engineering"‚Äî has quietly become a generalized skill of extreme intellectual precision via language.
fullText:
We've decided that AI makes us dumb, brainrot is real, and we're all forgetting how to write code.

This was my initial assumption, too.

But I've come to see things a little differently.

I actually think the opposite is happening.

The idea that we're all forgetting to write code is true, but misses the much bigger and more important point.

Yes, we are losing those reflexes for manual coding just like our ancestors lost the reflex for spear fishing or pottery.

But did society regress just because our ancestors forgot how to spear fish?

A more recent example is the early-early days of programming. There used to be people who knew how to program in assembly, and yes, I know some people still take pride in this, but realistically? We have collectively forgotten how to write assembly ‚Äî yet society moves forward faster than ever.

I believe the same is happening today. We're forgetting to write manually, write with pen and paper, and to code by hand. But that is ok.

On the other side of things, I feel my brain getting sharper, not duller, from having constant access to information.

At any moment of any day, I can now open my phone and find an answer to any question. And not only can I get instant access to information ‚Äî I can ask for corrections and feedback on my world view ‚Äî my mental model of how things work.

I think this is the real, insane superpower of AI that nobody is talking about. AI can give us extremely precise information to patch up gaps in our knowledge, allowing every person to have a more complete and accurate world view.

At the same time, it does require thought because AI is frequently wrong and hallucinates, so the user must actually engage with the AI and think critically.

Knowing what questions to ask and how to ask them is becoming an ever more important skill. What started out as "prompt engineering"‚Äî has quietly become a generalized skill of extreme intellectual precision via language. Millions of people are now practicing the art of saying exactly what they mean, every single day.

My ability to refine specific language around asking questions has dramatically improved, as has my ability to detect weird information that feels wrong or out of place. I'm constantly pushing back on the AI and disagreeing with it.

All of this said, there are still major problems with hallucinations and sycophancy which are unresolved, and which pose major threats.

Stories of AI psychosis are concerning and must be explored.

But the one thing that I am thoroughly convinced of is that those who choose to use AI to expand and deepen their thinking will receive a massive cognitive boost and form a more complete mental model of how the world works.

In a sense, I think of AI as a curiosity multiplier ‚Äî but this requires a baseline level of curiosity to multiply.

title: John Wick Is Getting A 3D Action Game, Lets You Murder Gangsters With Household Objects
description:
Keanu Reeves will take video game form once again in an as-yet-untitled John Wick 3D action game, based on the film franchise. The game's debut trailer during the February 2026 State of Play was mostly a slick, pre-rendered cinematic, but featured some gameplay footage at the end.
Saber Interactive is developing the game, in collaboration with Lionsgate, Keanu Reeves (who appears to be lending both his likeness and his voice), and John Wick director Chad Stahelski. The trailer cuts between the titular assassin trying on a new suit at a tailor, interspersed with Wick besting foes across a variety of locations. In one sequence, he is fighting goons in the kitchen of a Chinese restaurant and beats one man's head in with a frying pan.

title: A New Dead Or Alive Game Is In The Works
description:
During the February 12th State of Play broadcast, Koei Tecmo announced two upcoming projects related to the Dead or Alive fighting game series. The first, Dead or Alive 6 Last Round, is an update of 2019's Dead or Alive 6 for the PS5, with promises of new content and updates coming. Both full-price and free-to-play versions of the game will be available.
Four characters will be available in the free version of Dead or Alive 6 Last Round at launch, and going from previous series releases, the free-to-play version will likely contain a rotating roster of playable characters over time. DoA Quest, DoA Central, and a new photo mode will also be available.
fullText:
Producer Yosuke Hayashi announced the new project during the State of Play broadcast.

During the February 12th State of Play broadcast, Koei Tecmo announced two upcoming projects related to the Dead or Alive fighting game series. The first, Dead or Alive 6 Last Round, is an update of 2019's Dead or Alive 6 for the PS5, with promises of new content and updates coming. Both full-price and free-to-play versions of the game will be available.

Four characters will be available in the free version of Dead or Alive 6 Last Round at launch, and going from previous series releases, the free-to-play version will likely contain a rotating roster of playable characters over time. DoA Quest, DoA Central, and a new photo mode will also be available. The full-price package includes five previously DLC-only fighters, bringing the number of playable characters up to 29, and a selection of costumes for the whole cast.

Following the trailer, however, Hayashi also teased that a new Dead or Alive project is in the works. This comes during something of a renaissance for 3D fighting games, with a new Virtua Fighter title also in development. No further details are available at this time, but Koei Tecmo will no doubt release more information when they're ready.

title: Metal Gear Solid 4 And Peace Walker Coming As Metal Gear Solid Master Collection Vol. 2
description:
Konami is collecting a few more Metal Gear Solid games into the second volume of it Master Collection, and these ones are especially hard to play without their original hardware. The collection includes Metal Gear Solid 4: Guns of the Patriots, along with the PSP game Metal Gear Solid: Peace Walker, and the Game Boy Color game Metal Gear: Ghost Babel.
The trio of games are coming in the Metal Gear Solid Master Collection: Volume 2, which will be released on August 27. The collection was revealed during the PlayStation State of Play. The collection also includes a digital soundtrack.
fullText:
A few hard-to-find Metal Gear games are coming in August as part of the second MGS collection.

Konami is collecting a few more Metal Gear Solid games into the second volume of it Master Collection, and these ones are especially hard to play without their original hardware. The collection includes Metal Gear Solid 4: Guns of the Patriots, along with the PSP game Metal Gear Solid: Peace Walker, and the Game Boy Color game Metal Gear: Ghost Babel.

The trio of games are coming in the Metal Gear Solid Master Collection: Volume 2, which will be released on August 27. The collection was revealed during the PlayStation State of Play. The collection also includes a digital soundtrack.

The first Metal Gear Solid Master Collection included the first three MGS games, along with the original Metal Gear games for good measure.

For more, check out all the announcements from the PlayStation State of Play.

title: JPMorgan is reorganizing its commercial and investment bank as part of its AI push
description: JPMorgan appointed Guy Halamish as the chief operating officer of the corporate and investment bank as part of an effort to "maximize the impact of AI."
fullText:
JPMorgan is consolidating power to move faster on AI.

The bank is reshuffling its commercial and investment bank to "maximize the impact of AI," according to an internal memo seen by Business Insider that was sent this week.

The firm has named Guy Halamish as the chief operating officer of the CIB and tasked him with overseeing the ongoing effort to "harness the power of our data and fully leverage rapidly evolving AI capabilities," the memo, signed by the CIB's co-CEOs, Doug Petno and Troy Rohrbaugh, said. Halamish's new role was first reported by Bloomberg.

Under the new structure, each major business in the division, including banking, markets, payments, and securities services, will have its own chief data and analytics officer reporting jointly to Halamish and business heads. The bank recently hired Zachery Anderson as the chief data and analytics officer of its payments division, after a nearly six-year stint at UK-based lender NatWest. In a LinkedIn post about the new job, Anderson said he wants to push the "edge of the possible with AI."

The move is part of a new strategy to break silos across the unit and speed up adoption of AI.

The team of officers will work with the wider firm on a range of efforts, including "preparing our infrastructure for more advanced AI and the expanded use of AI agents" and "driving end-to-end transformation" in areas such as client onboarding.

The CIB is a huge profit driver for JPMorgan ‚Äî in 2024, it generated $25 billion in net income out of a firmwide total of $58.5 billion, according to that year's annual report.

JPMorgan, backed last year by an approximately $18 billion tech budget, is one of the financial industry's leaders in AI, with its own proprietary genAI platform and additional tools in the pipeline. CEO Jamie Dimon defended the firm's AI spending on a recent earnings call.

"We are going to stay out front, so help us God," Dimon said about the spending.

Work at JPMorgan or have a tip? Contact this reporter via email at atecotzky@insider.com or Signal at alicetecotzky.05. Use a personal email address and a nonwork device; here's our guide to sharing information securely.
