title: What's that? New Braum's under construction in OKC will be one of the largest in the state
description: A new 6,456-square-foot Braum‚Äôs store under construction at NW 192nd Street and N Western Avenue in Oklahoma City is valued at $2.5 million.
fullText:
Oklahoma City residents may have driven by the intersection of north Western Avenue and NW 192nd Street and wondered what‚Äôs being constructed there.

Braum‚Äôs in January 2025 filed a permit at 1021 NW 192nd Street to build what will be one of the larger stores in its footprint.

According to permits filed with the City of Oklahoma City, Braum‚Äôs is building a nearly 6,500-square-foot store. It‚Äôs a job with an estimated value of $2.5 million, the permit shows.

There are 326 Braum's stores in the U.S. as of Feb. 11, and Oklahoma has 146 of them, or about 45% of all locations nationally, data provided by the company.

With most Braum‚Äôs stores ranging from 5,500-6,500 square feet, the location being built on 192nd Street would be one of the largest in Oklahoma.

The Express Star reported in 2021 that Braum‚Äôs opened the largest location in Oklahoma at 3001 S. Sara Rd. The report states that location is just under 6,500 square feet, with seating for about 70 guests and an outdoor covered patio that accommodates roughly 40 patrons.

The 192nd Street location is of comparable size at 6,456 square feet.

Braum‚Äôs leadership, according to reports, has increased the size of new stores since the 2000s to accommodate their expanded Fresh Market grocery sections, which feature wider aisles and an increased variety of product options.

The markets inside the stores are among the qualities that separate the brand from other fast-food options.

The layout seen in Yukon and in Wolfforth, Texas, dedicates more than 1,600 square feet to the market area alone. Both of those locations have 16.5-foot ceilings, the largest in the company‚Äôs footprint.

Braum's Public Relations Director Amanda Beuchaw said the new store in Oklahoma City will be the same store model as seen in Yukon and just outside of Lubbock, Texas.

"The (store size) mostly has to do with the lot size," Beuchaw said. "If the lot is big enough to support it, they love to use the big model as much as they can because they really like the look and aesthetic of that model. But it has to do with the lot being able support that size of a store as well as the parking lot and the spaces needed."

Beuchaw said the company hopes to open the new location sometime before June 2026, but that will ultimately depend on weather and material delays, among other factors.

This article originally appeared on Oklahoman: Oklahoma City's new Braum's store will be one of the largest in the state

title: Virginia Supreme Court rules US Marine's adoption of an Afghan war orphan will stand
description: The Virginia Supreme Court ruled Thursday that a U.S. Marine and his wife will keep an Afghan orphan they brought home in defiance of a U.S. government decision to reunite her with her Afghan family.
fullText:
The Virginia Supreme Court ruled Thursday that a U.S. Marine and his wife will keep an Afghan orphan they brought home in defiance of a U.S. government decision to reunite her with her Afghan family. The decision likely ends a bitter, yearslong legal battle over the girl's fate.

In 2020, a judge in Fluvanna County, Virginia, granted Joshua and Stephanie Mast an adoption of the child, who was then 7,000 miles away in Afghanistan living with a family the Afghan government decided were her relatives.

Four justices on the Virginia Supreme Court on Thursday signed onto an opinion reversing two lower courts‚Äô rulings that found the adoption was so flawed it was void from the moment it was issued.

The justices wrote that a Virginia law that cements adoption orders after six months bars the child‚Äôs Afghan relatives from challenging the court, no matter how flawed its orders and even if the adoption was obtained by fraud.

Three justices issued a scathing dissent, calling what happened in this court ‚Äúwrong,‚Äù ‚Äúcancerous‚Äù and ‚Äúlike a house built on a rotten foundation.‚Äù

An attorney for the Masts declined to comment, citing an order from the circuit court not to discuss the details of the case publicly. Lawyers representing the Afghan family said they were not yet prepared to comment.

The child was injured on the battlefield in Afghanistan in September 2019 when U.S. soldiers raided a rural compound. The child‚Äôs parents and siblings were killed. Soldiers brought her to a hospital at an American military base.

The raid was targeting terrorists who had come into Afghanistan from a neighboring country; some believed she was not Afghan and tried to make a case for bringing her to the U.S. But the State Department, under President Donald Trump‚Äôs first administration, insisted the U.S. was obligated under international law to work with the Afghan government and the International Committee of the Red Cross to unite the child with her closest surviving relatives.

The Afghan government determined she was Afghan and vetted a man who claimed to be her uncle. The U.S. government agreed and brought her to the family. The uncle chose to give her to his son and his new wife, who raised her for 18 months in Afghanistan.

Meanwhile, Mast and his wife convinced courts in rural Fluvanna County, Virginia, to grant them custody and then a series of adoption orders, continuing to claim she was the ‚Äústateless‚Äù daughter of foreign fighters.

Judge Richard Moore granted them a final adoption in December 2020. When the six-month statute of limitations ran out, the child was still in Afghanistan living with her relatives, who testified they had no idea a judge was giving the girl to another family. Mast contacted them through intermediaries and tried to get them to send the girl to the U.S. for medical treatment but they refused to let her go alone.

When the U.S. military withdrew from Afghanistan and the Taliban took over, the family agreed to leave and Mast worked his military contacts to get them on an evacuation flight. Mast then took the baby from them at a refugee resettlement center in Virginia, and they haven‚Äôt seen her since.

The AP agreed not to name the Afghan couple because they fear their families in Afghanistan might face retaliation from the Taliban. The circuit court issued a protective order shielding their identities.

The Afghans challenged the adoption, claiming the court had no authority over a foreign child and the adoption orders were based on Mast repeatedly misleading the judge.

The Virginia Supreme Court on Thursday wrote that the law prohibiting challenges to an adoption after six months is designed to create permanency, so a child is not bounced from one home to another. The only way to undercut it is to argue that a parent‚Äôs constitutional rights were violated.

The lower courts had found that the Afghan couple had a right to challenge the adoption because they were the girl‚Äôs ‚Äúde facto‚Äù parents when they came to the United States.

Four of the Supreme Court judges ‚Äî D. Arthur Kelsey, Stephen R. McCullough, Teresa M. Chafin, Wesley G. Russell Jr. ‚Äî disagreed.

‚ÄúWe find no legal merit‚Äù in the argument that ‚Äúthat they were ‚Äòde facto‚Äô parents of the child and that no American court could constitutionally sever that relationship,‚Äù they wrote. They pointed to Fluvanna County Circuit Court Judge Richard Moore‚Äôs findings that the Afghan couple ‚Äúare not and never were parents‚Äù of the child, because they had no order from an Afghan court and had not proven any biological relationship to her.

The Afghans had refused DNA testing, saying it could not reliably prove a familial connection between opposite-gender half-cousins. They insisted that it didn't matter, because Afghanistan claimed the girl as its citizen and got to determine her next-of-kin.

The Supreme Court leaned heavily on a 38-page document written by Judge Moore, who granted the adoption, then presided over a dozen hearings after the Afghans challenged it. He wrote that he trusted the Masts more than the Afghans, and believed that the Masts‚Äô motivations were noble while the Afghans were misrepresenting their relationship to the child.

The Supreme Court also dismissed the federal government‚Äôs long insistence that Trump‚Äôs first administration had made a foreign policy decision to unite her with her Afghan relatives, and a court in Virginia has no authority to undo it. The government submitted filings in court predicting dire outcomes if the baby was allowed to remain with the Marine: it could be viewed as ‚Äúendorsing an act of international child abduction,‚Äù threaten international security pacts and be used as propaganda by Islamic extremists ‚Äî potentially endangering U.S soldiers overseas.

But the Justice Department in Trump‚Äôs second administration abruptly changed course.

The Supreme Court noted in its opinion that the Justice Department had been granted permission to make arguments in the case, but withdrew its request to do so on the morning of oral arguments last year, saying it ‚Äúhas now had an opportunity to reevaluate its position in this case.‚Äù

The Supreme Court returned repeatedly to Moore‚Äôs finding that giving the girl to the family ‚Äúwas not a decision the United States initiated, but rather consented to or acquiesced in.‚Äù

The three judges who dissented were unsparing in their criticism of both the Masts and the circuit court that granted him the adoption.

‚ÄúA dispassionate review of this case reveals a scenario suffused with arrogance and privilege. Worse, it appears to have worked,‚Äù begins the dissent, written by Justice Thomas P. Mann, and signed by Chief Justice Cleo E. Powell and LeRoy F. Millette, Jr.

A Virginia court never had the right to give the child to the Masts, the dissent said.

They castigated the Masts for ‚Äúbrazenly‚Äù misleading the courts during their quest to adopt the girl.

‚ÄúWe must recognize what an adoption really is: the severance and termination of the rights naturally flowing to an otherwise legitimate claimant to parental authority. Of course, the process must be impeccable. An evolved society could not sanction anything less than that. And here, it was less,‚Äù Mann wrote. ‚ÄúIf this process was represented by a straight line, (the Masts) went above it, under it, around it, and then blasted right through it until there was no line at all ‚Äî just fragments collapsing into a cavity.‚Äù
